story: NewsBrexit: Theresa May could back down in citizens rights row after ally blurts out planIn chaotic scenes, Home Secretary Sajid Javid said the government will accept an amendment on EU citizens rights - despite what Theresa May claimedShareCommentsByBen GlazeDeputy political editorPippa CrerarDaily Mirror Political EditorDan Bloom:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news politics video brexit-sajid-javid-confirms-government-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news politics  , theme : # , title : Mirror Politics ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news politics  , theme : # , title : Mirror Politics ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true""Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailTheresa May could back down over EU citizens rights in a No Deal Brexit to avoid another damaging Commons defeat. Cabinet minister Sajid Javid blurted out today that the Government will BACK a bid by Tory MP Alberto Costa in crunch Brexit votes tonight. Government aide Mr Costa faced being sackedTheresa May did not accept his amendment calling for a joint UK-EU commitment to protect the rights of expats, even in No Deal. Yesterday the Prime Minister stopped short of giving her support, instead saying: A separate agreement for citizens’ rights is something the EU have been clear they do not have the legal authority for. If it is not done in a Withdrawal Agreement, these issues become a matter for member states unless the EU were to agree a new mandate to take this forward. But today, in confusing scenes, the Home Secretary told MPs there was nothing wrong with an amendment by Mr Costa. And askedthe government was accept it now he replied decisively: Yes. UPDATED STORY BELOW:   Yet after a brief pause Mr Javid added quickly: What do you mean now  When was the government not supporting it  When did you hear that  An MP on the Commons Home Affairs Committee replied: Yesterday. Mr Javid said: From who  The MP said bluntly: From the Prime Minister. Mr Javid replied: Did you , before shting awkwardly in his seat. Dozens of Tory MPs including grandee Sir Graham Brady, a string of former ministers including Dominic Raab and Iain Duncan Smith, Remainer Dominic Grieve and Brexiteer Jacob Rees-Mogg signed Mr Costas amendment last night. Jeremy Corbyn had already committed Labour to supporting the plan.  MP Mr Costa told  News he was seeking urgent talks with Tory whips to find out what was going on. Mrs May pulled the sting out of the Brexit votes on Tuesday by vowing to give MPs votes on No Deal and delaying Brexit. But while she kicked her Brexit high noon down the road to mid-March, she still faced a series of potentially damaging defeats. A cross-party group of MPs led by Labours Jack Dromey and Tory Caroline Spelman tabled an amendment that would force the Government to hold a series of indicative votes on Britains future relationship with Europe on March . If successful, the move would set a precedent for Parliament taking control of the Brexit timetable, which the PM has fiercely opposed.  Tonight should also be the moment when Labour formally commits to supporting a second referendum when, as expected, its own Brexit alternative plan was defeated. However, there were early signs that some Tory eurosceptics could swing in behind the PMs deal. Leading Brexiteer Jacob Rees-Mogg told the FT he would be happy to accept an appendix to the deal rather than reopening the whole thing.

title: brexit tory jacob rees mogg
story: NewsBrexit: Tory Jacob Rees-Mogg signals he could back down and PASS a dealHis comments backing a potential revised deal are much softer than what he said before - but it may not be all it seemsShareCommentsByDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB NewsJacob Rees-Mogg, the ringleader of Tory Brexiteers, appears to have softened demands on Brexit "Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailTory ringleader Jacob Rees-Mogg has softened his position on Brexit in a signal he could back down and pass a deal.His comments come just hours after Theresa May opened the door to delay leaving the EU - Brexiteers worst nightmare. Yesterday Mr Rees-Mogg, who leads the anti-EU European Research Group, claimed a delay would be a plot to stop Brexit .And in a curious development, today he showed signs he could soften his demands to what he needs before passing a deal. The comments are crucial because they give Theresa May a tiny glimmer of hope that her Brexit deal could get across the line by March . However, sceptics also suggested Mr Rees-Moggs demands are still never going to be met and his softening could be a ploy to delay and decision and eventually trigger No Deal. Thats because, crucially, he is demanding a date on the Irish backstop - something the EU says it wont accept.   The row revolves around the Irish backstop, a clause in the -page Brexit deal that could extend EU customs rules over the UK from  January . On January , Mr Rees-Mogg declared: As long as the backstop is there I will not vote for this deal. But today the Tory appeared to drop his demand for the backstop itself - which is tied up in the unchanging -page deal - to be changed. Instead, he said he would accept an appendix added afterwards that adds extra certainty to the backstop. He said: It has to have equal weight to the Withdrawal Agreement. So,it were to be an appendix that would be satisfactory, but then the backstop is itself an appendix, so you can add to the Withdrawal Agreement without re-opening it, it seems to me. So, that would work, but it must be of equal legal standing.  If Mr Rees-Mogg and Tory Brexiteers were to team up with  Labour MPs who are against delaying Brexit, they could - in theory - delay Brexit.But his comments by no means clear the way for Theresa Mays deal to pass by March . Thats because Mr Rees-Mogg is still demanding a date on the backstop - something the EU have said wont happen. He told the BBC: I can live with the de facto removal of the backstop, evenit isnt de jure. What do I mean by that  I mean thatthere is a clear date that says the backstop ends, and that that is in the text of the treaty, or equivalent to the text of the treaty.  If it were to be an appendix to the treaty - bear in mind the Irish backstop is in itself an appendix to the treaty - so,you had a further appendix that said this will not go beyond a particular date - and a short date, not a long date - then that would remove the backstop in the letime of parliament. And that would have a reasonable effect, from my point of view. It came as the Tory party descended into a row over the bid to delay Brexit. Theresa May today urges MPs to do their duty and vote for her deal by March  so our country can move forward. She adds I do not want to see Article  extended and I firmly believe that a deal is within our grasp. But dramatic reports have emerged of a row at yesterdays Cabinet meeting where the PM unveiled a plan to delay. Commons leader Andrea Leadsom branded her Remainer colleagues - who forced the PM into a U-turn - disgraceful, appalling and disloyal, its claimed.  And Liz Truss, Chief Secretary to the Treasury, accused them of kamikaze behaviour, according to reports. Defence Secretary Gavin Williamson said speaking out against No Deal had totally undermined the PMs negotiating position in Brussels and her ability to deliver her deal successfully, according to the Daily Mail. One of the Remainer posse, Claire Perry, is said to have muttered: Oh for Gods sake, Andrea! Chancellor Philip Hammond is said to have joined calls for a delay. Backbench Tories were furious at the prospect of a delay.Two Tories, Priti Patel and Grant Shapps, today warn: Voting to extend Article  is a vote for a second referendum.

title: labour really been too apologetic
story: NewsopinionHas Labour really been too apologetic about anti-Semitism  Er, noIt hasnt actually apologised, says Fleet Street Fox. And thats the problemShareCommentsByFleet Street FoxColumnist:,  FEB Newsopinion"Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailIts not surprising that one of Labours most dishonourable members was recorded saying the party had been too apologetic for the anti-Semitism that infects it.What is surprising is that a roomful of people applauded and laughed at Chris Williamsons claim, despite the fact they are all grown-ups and must surely know what an apology looks and sounds like.The dictionary defines the word apology as: A written or spoken expression of ones regret, remorse, or sorrow for having insulted, failed, injured, or wronged another.And heres the thing. Theres been no apology worthy of the description. The idea that an absence of contrition is, somehow, an overdose of the stuff is straight out of an Orwellian nightmare. There have been plenty of not-pologies: sorry for offence caused, sorry for pain and distress, sorryanyone thinks weve let them down, sorry but its not my fault. Its the same as apologising for the train being late to Auschwitz, in that it doesnt exactly address the real problem.Anti-Semitism has been eating the Labour Partys reputation from the feet up for  years. And what has Labour done about it  . Didnt immediately kick out all the anti-Semites When Ken Livingstones mouth kept saying stupid things about Hitler, he was suspended, then suspended again, and eventually resigned claiming I abhor anti-Semitism while making it quite clear he didnt know what it was. Momentum vice-chairman Jackie Walker was suspended twice in , first for claiming Jews financed the slave trade and then for saying she couldnt find a definition of anti-Semitism she could work with. She demanded Jewish MP Luciana Berger be censured for complaining. The party promised the case would be dealt with last year, but its still in abeyance. For every election candidate caught claiming our children are being brainwashed into thinking Hitler was the bad guy and suspended, dozens more are not. Labour had about  complaints of anti-Semitism, and still had  of them to deal with last year. Deputy Leader Tom Watson has just sent them another  - make that , with Mr Williamsons contribution.Someone will say Labour is merely obeying its rules and giving everyone a fair hearing. But justice delayed is justice denied, and you dont kill a virus by letting it live a bit longer. . Couldnt agree what anti-Semitism is  The scandal forced Labour to become the first mainstream party to have rules on anti-Semitism which it could use to discipline people.But despite the fact % of its members backed the International Holocaust Remembrance Alliances definition, activists argued the Jews had got it wrong. They caused months of damaging headlines as they tried to contextualise it, before the partys ruling body stepped in to overrule them.. Allowed anti-Semitism at the launch of its anti-Semitism report  To prove he was serious about stopping this, Jeremy Corbyn ordered a report from Shami Chakrabarti, who had been hurriedly made a party member and thereafter a baroness. He invited one of his own MPs, Ruth Smeeth, to the press conference. She had supported him previously and he hoped shed tell journalists Labour was cool with Jews.An activist was handing out leaflets. Ruth asked for one. The activist refused and wrote her name down for talking to journalists. He later took the microphone and accused her of colluding. Corbyn said nothing, but later apologised to the activist for the fact hed been knocked over at a previous event.Corbyn knew anti-Semitism was bad enough for his image that he needed a report into it he knew it needed support from his Jewish MPs so invited some he had, one hopes, read the report and knew accusations of collusion were an anti-Semitic trope and when it happened in front of him, he apologised to the anti-Semite.The activist was later expelled from the party - but too late to stop the damage he had done.. Kept doing anti-Semitic things A Jewish MP has been hounded out of the Labour Party. Other MPs have left after being subjected to interrogations for criticising anti-Semitism. Councillors have resigned, and tens of thousands of members have left.Shadow Chancellor John McDonnell is chairman of the Labour Representation Committee, a pressure group within the party, which has described the scandal as ruling class propaganda.And it has questioned even today why Hezbollahs political wing is a proscribed terrorist organisation on the basis it has been democratically elected. Never mind that its waging a holy war against Jews.. Failed to figure out what an apology was When Bradford West MP Naz Shah was found to have written posts on Facebook that appeared to support the deportation of Jews, she was suspended. She spoke and more importantly LISTENED to the Jewish community, and issued fulsome apologies in the Jewish News, House of Commons, and media interviews. She said: The language that I used was anti-Semitic, it was offensive. What I did was hurt people. She showed remorse. She acknowledged the harm she had done and explained how it had happened. She changed her behaviour. She was, quite rightly, given another chance.Corbyn has admitted Labour has not done enough. He has said Jews deserve an apology. And his statements been misreported as apologies, when theyre not. An apology would say: I did not realise when I was campaigning for peace in the Middle East it might have worked betterId spoken to some Jews. I failed to be decisive because it would mean admitting Id been wrong. Labour has a historic problem with Jews, and Im going to fix it.  The most anti-Semitic thing Labour has done is not a single, shocking case: its the total inability to stop the stench of anti-Semitism being its biggest problem. The obtuse, blinkered, ignorant and arrogant refusal to clean its own wound. Thats what convinces Jew-haters they have found a home. It becomes normal to ask whether someones ethnicity or religion makes them unacceptable, to say the Jews are making it up. It becomes OK to applaud a man who says you can apologise too much.Harbouring a disease means you ARE the disease. Labours inability to lead means others who share none of its values get a free pass to hate Jews more loudly, and to hand out the same bile to other races, sexualities, abilities and faiths.Labour has not apologised enough for the hate it has allowed to fester. It can start by kicking out Chris Williamson, and every single person who applauded him.

title: boy deformed foot told you
story: NewsDisabled boy told you can put one foot in front of other before benefits axedLeon Beamon, from Kidsgrove, Staffordshire, has been left to use his wheelchair to get to and from school because he suffers pain after walking for just five minutesShareCommentsByRuby DaviesLucy Clarke-BillingsDeputy News Editor:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news uk-news video schoolboy-leon-beamon-disability-living-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news uk-news  , theme : # , title : Mirror UK News ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news uk-news  , theme : # , title : Mirror UK News ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true""Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe family of a six-year-old boy with a deformed ankle have been stripped of their specialised car and pound,-a-year allowance - after being told he can put one foot in front of the other. Leon Beamon had always qualied for Disability Living Allowanceever since he was born with a condition which affected the growth of his left leg. The primary school pupil has already undergone numerous operations, wears a shield around his ankle, leg and foot, and faces more hospital procedures.But mum, Kelly, is devastated after the Department for Work and Pensionsstopped the DLA funding which was partly used to fund the car, StokeonTrentLive reports.Now Leon, from Kidsgrove, Staffordshire, has been left to use his wheelchair to get to and from his school because he suffers pain after walking for just five minutes.Mother-of-two Kelly is Leons carer and is now on Universal Credit .  The -year-old said: When Leon was born his left leg wasnt growing properly and had fused to his ankle bone which caused a deformity. He had an operation to try to correct his ankle deformity and was told it will never be  per cent. Also to en the part of his leg that isnt growing he needs another two operations on his bone in the future. He also has to wear a shield around his leg, ankle and foot. Without the mobility car weve had to walk to school and hes been forced to use his wheelchair because hes in so much pain. The walk to school is uphill and to force him to walk would be cruel. Leon loves the outdoors but without the car I have no way of taking him anywhere as the wheelchair limits the places we can go to without the car. Leon cant understand why it has gone.   I have appealed against the decision to stop his allowance. But the DWP stands by its decision because he can put one foot in front of the other and can cross the road. But its not that simple. His hospital consultant has confirmed Leon has limited mobility in his ankle, he requires extra supervision during school activities, and requires a wheelchair on any walk over five minutes - but the DWP says he can walk. Leon was on the higher rate because of his limited mobility and I could understandthey had put him on the lower rate but to stop it altogether I cant understand it.  Grandmother Janys Wright has been left disgusted by the DWPs decision. She said: This decision is totally ridiculous. The DWP has defended its decision. A spokesman said: We’re committed to ensuring that every child gets the very best chances in le which is why we’re spending more than ever before on DLA for disabled children. Decisions on DLA for children are made following consideration of all the information provided by the family and their GP or medical specialist, and anyone who disagrees with a decision can appeal.

title: brutal pub landlord lauded sticking
story: NewsBrutal pub landlord is praised for sticking it to terrible TripAdvisor reviewersRoger Cazaly, landlord Plume of Feathers in Portscatho, Cornwall, gives honest responses to criticism the pub receives on TripAdvisorShareCommentsByLee TrewhelaBradley Jolly:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB NewsLandlord of the Plume of Feathers pub in Portscatho, Roger Cazaly "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email A pub landlord has been praised for his honest - and often brutal - responses to scathing TripAdvisor reviews.Roger Cazaly, who runs the Plume of Feathers in Portscatho, Cornwall with we Helen, gives as good as he gets on the website. The quaint th Century pub near the beach has received more than  “excellent” or “very good” reviews on TripAdvisor. The Plume has four stars out of five with  reviews, where it is listed as second out of nine restaurants in Portscatho. However, there are  “terrible” critiques from members of the public - which he often challenges. Roger told one diner he hadn’t “cringed this much in a long time” at their post. He compared another to “a small child that can’t have a biscuit. Many people on social media have praised Rogers attitude. I think the pub Landlord sounds like a legend, wrote one woman. Another posted: Excellent answers! Well done the landlord...Another Facebook user wrote: I want to go just to meet the Landlord. What a legend! I loved his responses. Cornwall Live compiled some of Rogers best responses... Complaint  One diner put on TripAdvisor: Just popped in for some food, was told they were too busy. Said we’d just have some drinks, they basically suggested that go someone . Rude, arrogant. Rogers y reply read: “Now now Kitty, its not nice to call people names. But seeing as youve decided to go on the worldwide web and call me names like a little child who didnt get what she wanted when she demanded it, let’s talk about your visit. “Folks, it was a Saturday evening on the bank holiday weekend of the half term, it was between  and .pm. This is possibly the most premium time food wise in any restaurant or pub, especially in a little Cornish pub in the middle of a holiday destination. We were at full flow, every table taken, tables had been booked weeks in advance, the kitchen is maxed out. “However, Kittyminx,she comes to the bar with her children and says Chips, I want chips for my children. I responded with an apology and said thats fine but there will probably be about a  or  minute wait and probably apologised again. “You seemed stunned by this, so I went onto explain that we were absolutely maxed out and there will be a waityou want to go ahead and order then we had that awful  or  seconds where you just blinked and stared at me like I was speaking a foreign language, so I then said the taverna down the road is open and they do takeaway food as well, which might be a better option at this moment in time . “I actually thought I was being helpful, giving you options, but obviously you didnt see it this way. Someone dared to say no to Kittyminx! “Now, Kittyminx, when you leave ‘reviews’ like this, it actually says more about you than the venue. Because, generally, we then go into your profile and read your other reviews and have a little chuckle. You use the words Rude and Arrogant with gay abandon dont you  We read about when you complain that the waitress had asked you to stop your children playing on the stairs  times, the poor girl … or when another venue got slagged off because you werent allowed to move the furniture … Kitty, you had probably put [it] in front of a fire escape or something. “Trust me Kittyminx, when it comes to rude and arrogant you might want to look a little closer to home.”   Complaint  Another diner was upset with birthday celebrations at the pub. They wrote: “We had waited all summer to have a meal at the Plume of Feathers ... very popular with tourists, no chance for locals! “We booked for Monday night as it was the actual birthday! Bad mistake! We were squeezed into a passageway! With another table reserved for later making it a very tight squeeze! We had three courses: soup, main, dessert all were warm and the meat was very tough! “Chips were under-cooked and soggy! The waiter was over the top with compliments which appeared to put pressure on us! No extra attention though given to the birthday men! I.e. a candle in their dessert or an extra biscuit! The waiter was told two of the party had birthdays! The bill was expensive to the quality of the meal! “So … tourists you are welcome to the Plume of Feathers we will not be going back! A little attention would have been lovely evenit was to sit in a restaurant with a table laid and flowers present! Then the bill wouldnt have mattered! Very disappointing as we are locals!” But in a y reply, Roger defended the boozer. He wrote: “ exclamation points!! !! Folks, here we have the very controversial ‘locals’ scenario. This seems to happen in two locations, Cumbria and Cornwall. “When someone says they are a ‘local’, this is not to be confused with a ‘regular’. When someone enters your premises and keeps dropping ‘were locals, dont you know’ into the conversation, generally, theyre not really. “Quite often they will be from outside the county, say, somewhere like Peterborough, and theyve just moved down very recently and immediately want all the trimmings of being a ‘local’. If you dont treat them as such, evenyou have never seen them ever before in your le, they will scuttle off and go on TripAdvisor. If you do, they are full of praise and everything is wonderful. But, we just treat everyone the same. title: c section carried out woman
story: NewsC-section carried out on woman fatally injured in car crash who wasnt pregnantAdele Barbour, , suffered a heart attack after a car crash on the A near Lincoln, an inquest heardShareByDanielle Hoe:,  FEB NewsAdele Barbour died in hospital after a crash on the A near Lincoln"Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA woman had an emergency c-section carried out on her after medics mistakenly thought she was pregnant after a fatal car crash, an inquest heard. Adele Barbour tragically died as a result of the collision on the A near Lincoln. The -year-old died in hospital after a cardiac arrest, Lincolnshire Live reports. Questions were raised by coroner Marianne Johnson on the actions of emergency workers who mistakenly thought she was pregnant. An investigation was launched by the East Midlands Ambulance Service. Miss Barbour died on January  last year as she had pulled in front of a Toyota Yaris while trying to turn right.   She had been indicating right off the A to turn into Wash Dyke Lane when she pulled in front of the Yaris travelling on the other side of the road. Miss Barbour had a cardiac arrest and was rushed to hospital. However, questions were raised by coroner Marianne Johnson at the inquest into her death on the actions of emergency workers who mistakenly thought she was pregnant. A C-section was carried out at the hospital because they thought she might have a baby due to her protruding stomach - only for them to discover she was not pregnant. At an inquest held at the Lincoln Cathedral Centre on Tuesday, February  a collision investigator was called to give his report on the circumstances of the crash. PC Mark Brown said in his evidence: “Adele Barbour has failed to give way at the junction. She has pulled into the path of a Toyota Yaris across in the south-west-bound lane. “For an unknown reason she has not seen the oncoming Toyota Yaris. “Adele Barbour was driving her black Vauxhall Meriva on the A Lincoln Road at Nettleham. “She had started to turn right and has failed to give way and driven into the path of an oncoming Yaris. “The other driver was confronted by a car in her carriageway and had no way to avoid it. “There is no evidence that herdriving caused the collision.” At the inquest, a post mortem investigation gave the medical cause of deathas a laceration of the aorta. Witness Nicola Ware was one of the first on scene of the collision. She was driving to work as a paramedic for East Midlands Ambulance Service. When she arrived, she said Miss Barbour was sitting conscious in her car and complaining of back pain. She said: “I went towards the car that Adele was in. I asked her name and said that I was an off-duty paramedic on my way to work. “I asked hershe had any pain and she said that she had pain in her back and that she had a pre-existing back condition. “She did not mentionshe was pregnant. She had a large puffa jacket on so I had no reason to believe that she was. “I proceeded to the other car and I phoned the control roomto explain that I would be late and I was told it would be a while before getting a crew on the scene.   “Another lady at the scene then shouted me back across to Adele as she thought she was fitting. “She was unconscious but she had a pulse and she was breathing. “The fire service arrived and I asked them to help me to get her out of the car and she went into cardiac arrest.” Other paramedics from the private medical group Elite EMS and LIVES also arrived at the scene to help. Staff who arrived on scene raised concerns that Miss Barbour may have been pregnant due to a protruding stomach so precautionary measures were made while giving her CPR. The inquest also heard evidence from James Bidwell from Elite EMS, Chris Cole, a paramedic at LIVES, and Emma Haskey, a clinical support manager at EMAS. A GP report read out at the inquest said that she had received major surgery in  for spina bida and was also diagnosed with chronic leukaemia in . In all of the live evidence given, it was heard that the decision was made to move Miss Barbour to Lincoln County Hospital due to her unstable state and repeat cardiac arrests, unavailability of the air ambulance and the possibility that she may have been pregnant. Evidence from Emma Haskey heard at the inquest said: “In a pre-alert to the hospital I informed them there was a female patient after a road traffic collision with a query to whether she was eight months pregnant and that I would update them with more information when I could. “Later I was updated by the Emergency Operations Centre who told me that a C-section was carried out and the patient was found not to be pregnant.” Sam Smith of EMAS concluded: “In my opinion from the evidence I don’t think that the crew could have done any more than they did. “I would not recommend a dferent course of action.” The inquest is due to conclude today.

story: NewsGatwick earthquake: Magnitude . tremor shakes homes at amThe earthquake struck just before .am and roused people from their sleep in Greater London, West Sussex and SurreyShareCommentsByChris kitching:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news video gatwick-earthquake-struck-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news uk-news  , theme : # , title : Mirror UK News ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news uk-news  , theme : # , title : Mirror UK News ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true""Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailAn earthquake with a magnitude of . on the Richter scale was felt by thousands of Britons near Gatwick Airport overnight. The tremor was felt in Newdigate, Surrey, less than  miles from Gatwick Airport, at .am, according to the British Geological Survey . It was felt by people living in Greater London, West Sussex, Surrey and surrounding areas in southern England, and is said to have shaken houses and blocks of flats. Residents have complained that earthquakes have become a regular thing, with campaigners blaming oil drilling at sites in Horse Hill and Brockham - despite a report stating there is no causal link. It is the fourth recorded quake in the area in the last fortnight, with the ground having moved on February , and twice on Valentines Day. Tuesdays movement was the strongest, however, after the BGS recorded a . magnitude tremor on February , and . and . quakes on February . Earlier reports said the latest tremor had a magnitude of . but this has now been measured as . on the Richter scale. Gatwick Airport confirmed they had felt the tremors overnight, but airport operations had not been affected. A spokesman said: The team overnight felt the effect in the airport and the terminals.Did you feel the tremor this morning  Email webnews@mirror Debbie Worster, from Meath Green in Horley, told Surrey Live: Woke up at about am to what we thought was a helicopter right overhead, shut the windows and went back to sleep, then woke up with the whole house shaking. Very scary. Mhairi Cummins said: We all felt this one. It was huge - a big loud bang and rumble. It woke me and other friends around the village. Something is clearly wrong. Someone needs to start taking this seriously. We can’t be having all these earthquakes for no reason. Another who felt the tremor told the : Our mirrored wardrobe was shaking like crazy. My husband thought it was a train going by. It was very strong and quite frightening. And Steve Goddard said: We awoke at - am this morning by a shaking house. Lived here over  years - never had anything like that before. Twitter was abuzz with reports after the quake hit in the early morning hours on Wednesday, with many coming from Crawley, near Gatwick Airport. ITV weather presenter and meteorologist Laura Tobin wrote: Did you feel an #earthquake this morning  One hit near Gatwick at :am and measured magnitude ., early reports said. There were no reports of damage. Sarah Poole, from Capel near Dorking said: There was another earthquake this morning I felt it at .am. Wardrobe, bed, and windows shaking - biggest one yet. I posted straight away on Facebook and friends from surrounding areas had felt it too. Another Twitter user wrote: Th #earthquake this morning was mad!!!!!!! I thought my building was going to collapse! And one added: Did you hear about another #earthquake near Gatwick last night  Blocks of flats and houses shaking. Becoming regular thing. Another wrote: First time being woken up by an earthquake thought I was dreaming that whole bed and house was shaking, then got up and checked social media. And one added: That earthquake in Gatwick actually just woke me up from a deep sleep - terrying. Paige Knox said she thought she was dreaming but quickly realised her flat was shaking.She added: I woke up to my whole bed and flat shaking! I was so scared! James King, councillor for South Park and Woodhatch tweeted at .am: Was that an earthquake in Reigate just now  A number of residents blamed recent tremors on fracking in Surrey, but a report from the Oil and Gas Authority confirms fracking has not been undertaken in the area. One wrote: @Gatwick_Airport anybody there feel the latest earthquake  You guys can’t be happy about the amount of these we’ve had since the fracking started in Horse Hill!  After an estimated  tremors occurred between April and September last year, an investigation led by the British Geological Survey found that they were due to natural causes, Surrey Live reported. A report by the Oil and Gas Authority concluded that there was no causal link between oil activity in the area and the earthquakes. An excerpt from the report read: The workshop participants concluded that, based on the evidence presented, there was no causal link between the seismic events and oil and gas activity. Campaigners, however, were not convinced by the reports findings. Oil exploration at sites at Horse Hill and Brockham have been named by anti-oil activity protesters as the potential cause of the tremors.

story: NewsMan ordered to pay £, child support for daughter he didnt know existedRoss Mclaughlan, , from Stockton-on-Tees, County Durham, says he was was shocked when he received the Child Maintenance Service letter telling him he had a teenage daughterShareCommentsByTanveer Mann:,  FEB NewsRoss Mclaughlan, , was shocked when he received the CMS letter in , telling him he had a teenage daughter "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailAn oil rig worker claims he has been ordered to pay pound, in child support to a -year-old daughter he didnt know existed. Ross Mclaughlan, , says he was left speechless when he received a letter from the Child Maintenance Service back in  telling him he had a teenage daughter. The -year-old, from Stockton-on-Tees, County Durham, was not married and claims he had no idea who the girls mum was.He told the Daily Mail : I was so confused and didn’t recognise either the girl’s name or her mother’s, but told myself they’d either got the wrong Ross Mclaughlan, or that someone had targeted me as part of some scam.I was very wrong. It’s eight years since that letter arrived and, despite me never having seen or even spoken to the girl named in it, nor having any contact with her mother, I’ve had pound, deducted from my wages and been told I owe a further pound,.”   Ross says he initially tried to ignore the letter but then decided to pay the pound-a-month sum so it wouldnt jeopardise his job. He refused to take a DNA test as he felt it went against his human rights. But four years ago, he was hit with another letter from the CMS, telling him that the child support costs were increasing to pound a month. If he paid, it would mean he was left with an income of just pound after tax.   So he decided to look into the case further and request a copy of the girls birth certicate, which he says showed a dferent mans name under the father section - one who had the same surname as the girl and her mother. Ross immediately wrote to the CMS hoping that would be enough evidence to prove he wasnt the father and stop the payments. But he received a reply saying the certicate was not enough proof that the man was the child’s biological dad and so the money kept going out of his account. Things got even worse when the daughter turned  and he was told that he would have to pay a further pound, in retrospective payments. Ross described the whole case as being extortion and likened it to something that happens in a fascist state.   The woman claims she fell pregnant after a short fling with Ross and gave birth to their daughter in June . Her ex-husband allegedly became suspicious and requested a DNA test which proved the girl wasnt his, according to the woman. The daughter told the paper that she did wonder why Ross didnt get in touch when he found out about her from the CSA. A spokesman for the Department of Work and Pensions, which oversees the CMS, said: “We noty people before making deductions, to ensure they have a chance to contest parentage. When parentage is disputed we look for conclusive proof such as a DNA test or a court declaration. A birth certicate can be used as evidence, but would be discountedthere’s a suggestion that it’s unreliable.

story: NewsMeghan Markle finally perfects royal curtsy while greeting King of MoroccoThe Duchess of Sussex has been criticised for her curtsy in the past - but a royal expert says it appears she has had helpShareCommentsByDanya BazaraaNews Reporter:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news uk-news offline video meghan-markle-curtsies-meets-king-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news uk-news  , theme : # , title : Mirror UK News ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news uk-news  , theme : # , title : Mirror UK News ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true""Get the biggest Royal Family stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email Meghan Markle showed shes finally perfected a curtsy fit for a princess as she met the King of Morocco. The Duchess and Duke of Sussex ended their three day tour of the North African country this week by spending around an hour with King Mohammed VI at his private residence, surrounded by his immediate family.Video footage captures the moment they arrived at the residence on Monday night, full of smiles. title: mum begs help after bullied
story: NewsMum begs for help after bullied daughter, , tries to kill herself FIVE timesSchoolgirl Kara Clarke, from East Kilbride, Scotland, said she struggled to find a release from her mental and physical tormentShareCommentsByAndrea Lambrou:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB NewsMum Josephine Clarke says daughter Kara was targeted from day one "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA terried mum has begged for help to stop her daughter “becoming another statistic” after the -year-old tried to kill herself five times in just five months. Brave Kara Clarke told the Daily Record how she has been attacked, called names and had ‘vicious lies’ spread about her since starting school in August. Her mum, Josephine, called on the authorities to help get to grips with bullying, saying her daughter had been “targeted from day one”. The schoolgirl, from East Kilbride, was removed from her classes by her family, who say she was “beaten up inside and outside school grounds”. Soon after the bullying started, Kara says she struggled to find a release from her mental and physical torment, and took the decision to try and kill herself.   Heartbroken mum, Josephine, said: “I don’t want my girl to become another statistic. “Things got to such an extreme that Kara tried to kill herself on a number of occasions – she’s even self harmed IN school. The worst attempt was in November when she tried to jump off a bridge at lunchtime. “She was kept in hospital for four days. Now she’s self-harming and I’ve had to remove everything from the house and her room that she could use to hurt herself.” Police Scotland confirmed they responded to a call from Josephine on November  where she raised concerns for the wellbeing of her daughter, and that Kara had been taken to hospital. Kara’s first attempt on her le came two weeks after the sudden death of a -year-old Strathaven Academy pupil – a tragedy that left staff and pupils devastated.   “The same officer who came out was the one who responded to the incident involving the young girl from Strathaven Academy”, said Josephine. “I really felt for him, I couldn’t even imagine dealing with that.” The Daily Record understands Duncanrig held an assembly about bullying following that horror, but pupils were never officially informed about any incidents. Describing how the bullies make her feel, Kara said: “I’m silently in tears, but it’s not sad tears, it’s more rage. “The anger that builds up inside scares me. Part of me is happy to be out of the school, but part of me misses being with my friends. “And I’m missing art class, which I love.” Lindsayfield mum-of-four, Josephine, says a safety plan was put in place for Kara – who is currently being assessed for autism and ADHD – by the school. That saw her spend intervals and lunch breaks in a room accompanied by a friend and teacher.  But the childcare student claims the school broke the agreement after just one month, leading to Kara being attacked on school grounds and making another attempt on her le. Josephine says an emergency meeting with, school staff and the family was held. Kara’s guidance teacher, a school nurse, social worker and representatives from child and adolescent mental health servicesare said to have been there, with police offering input. She added: “The school put a safety plan in place where she wasn’t allowed on ‘the street’ where all the kids congregate because that’s where most of the issues were happening. “She got put into a room at intervals and lunchtime and wasn’t even allowed to go to the toilet herself – that’s how bad things were. The school breached the safety plan by allowing Kara back onto ‘the street’ without my knowledge. “She was attacked, but I was never informed about any incident or assault – it’s simply not acceptable. What happened to getting it right for every child  “Kara has been left feeling like she is the one always being punished.” Josephine has now taken steps to have Kara transferred to another South Lanarkshire school, telling us that her daughter “loves school and loves to learn” and that she “has her future all mapped out”. She added: “I don’t want her to lose that love, but I’m constantly in fear of what she might do. “I’m too scared to even go into her room in the morning wonderingshe is going to be alive. That’s how bad it is.” Head of education for the council, Lynn Sherry – who deals with support services and the school estate – said: “Anyone reading this story cannot fail to see that this is about the mental health and wellbeing of a very vulnerable young person. “There are genuine concerns that this sort of public exposure can only add to that vulnerability. We fully understand and share the concerns raised by the mum about her daughter, and would like to make it clear there has been signicant ongoing support from the school and health colleagues over a period of time to help deal with the mental health and wellbeing of this vulnerable young girl. “This will continue to be the case with the school pursuing expert help.” Whatever youre going through, the Samaritans are there to listen any time, free from any phone on  . They are there round the clock,  hours a day,  days a year. For more information on how they can help, visit their website here .

title: nurse dying leukaemia could saved
story: NewsNurse dying of leukaemia could be saved by drug - but she cant have it on NHSHeather Bellamy from Downham Market, Norfolk, worked as an NHS nurse for  years until she became too illShareCommentsByJane LavenderErin Cardf:,  FEB NewsHeather has been told theres nothing more the NHS can do for her "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email A terminally nurse who has worked for the NHS for  years has been told there is a drug that could save her le - but it isnt available on the NHS. Heather Bellamy is battling leukaemia for the fourth time.As well as gruelling chemotherapy she has also had to unsuccessful stem cell transplants and has now been told there is nothing more the NHS can do for her. But a drug, Idha, could save her le as shes one of a number of patients struck down by the disease because of a gene mutation. While Idha is available in the US it has not yet been licensed in the UK and Heather has been told the NHS will not pay for her treatment.   Now, her desperate family have launched an appeal to raise the pound, so she can travel to America and have the drug. Her father, John, said: “Heather was a nurse for  years before she became too sick to work, first in neonatal care then as a nurse advisor at NHS Direct. After that she became a community nurse then a lead practice nurse in respiratory care, helping people with asthma and the lung disease COPD lead better lives. “Her career was so important to her, and she helped so many people – but now she is the one who needs help and I am praying everyone will help her.” Heather is determined to stay alive for her four children, Lilly, , Alice, , Alfie,  and Sam, , and her parents, John, , and Angela, , are doing everyting they can to get her the treatment. Angela, a former teacher, said: “We’ve spoken to lots of people, from consultants to MPs about Idha, and the hope is that it will be available in the UK one day – but not in time for Heather. “It’s very dficult knowing there is something in the world that can help, but feeling held back by red tape.”   Mum-of-four Heather, of Downham Market, Norfolk, was first diagnosed with acute myeloid leukaemia, a cancer of the blood cells, in December . Years earlier she had her thyroid removed, meaning she had annual blood tests to monitor her progress – one of which detected her cancer. John, who has retired from the RAF, said: “A routine blood test in  revealed she had leukaemia. “It was incredibly shocking. Angela and I hadn’t even heard her say she’d been feeling unwell. It was an awful lot to take in. “We found out over the phone, as we were living in Spain. It’s one of those things you don’t ever think will happen to you.” From there, Heather had three rounds of chemotherapy and went into remission. But, less than a year later as she prepared toto work as a nurse, she relapsed in September .  Angela said: “We thought we could move on and put this horrible thing behind us – but then it came back, and so the search began for a stem cell donor. Sadly, none of her family were a match.”Heather’s search for a donor was successful but the transplant itself was put on hold when she developed sepsis , when the body attacks itself in response to an infection.Thankfully, she pulled through and after more chemotherapy at Addenbrooke’s Hospital in Cambridge, had her first transplant in February , using stem cells provided by an anonymous donor. Angela said: “It all seemed to go well, but by the summer of  she had relapsed again, and doctors discovered that she also had the IDH gene mutation. “After that, Heather had more chemotherapy before she ended up in intensive care when she had sepsis a second time. “She was too ill to attend her daughter Alice’s graduation, which she was very upset about.” A second stem cell transplant followed in October  and, once again, Heather and her family felt optimistic for the future when it appeared to have worked.  Every month that passed with her still in remission allowed her hope to grow stronger. But then, in December , she was dealt unbearable news for the fourth time. Angela said: “She’d been in remission for long enough to begin to hope, but then we got the news she had relapsed again. “She tells us her strength comes from the love for her four children and to be there for them when they need her. Its remarkable that shes kept going. Currently having chemotherapy to help manage her symptoms rather than cure her, Heather, who has an incredibly supportive partner Max, , has been warned that there are no further treatments available on the NHS. So, her family are determined to get her to the USA, where she will be able to receive Idha, which doctors there are able to prescribe. In patients like Heather, the IDH mutation blocks young blood cells in the bone marrow from maturing into healthy adult cells – but, Idha works by releasing this block.  To fund transport, accommodation, hospital bills and the drug itself, though, the Bellamys are facing a mammoth target of pound,. A GoFundMe page has already raised more than pound, in just a month and Angela and John are now praying kind strangers will keep helping them to keep their daughter alive. John said: People have been incredible. We want to thank every single person who has helped out so far. “The community has rallied round, but the problem we have is getting Heather’s story out there on a wider scale. “There must be somebody out there that can help us. All we want is to keep her alive. “We have been racking our brains to think of fundraising ideas outside the box. Somebody out there, whether its entrepreneurs, big companies or even football clubs may be able to help us. To donate, visit www.gofundme auntie-heather

story: NewsMum horried to discover whats inside bizarre pods she found in her gardenA mum turned to the internet for help after spotting some rather sinister looking pods dangling from a nearby treeShareCommentsByCourtney PochinAudience Writer:,  FEB NewsA mum found sinister pods on her neighbours tree "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailIf youve ever seen the  film, Invasion of the Body Snatchers, then youll know you should be y wary of bizarre pods. In a post on Facebook , the Australian woman wrote: At the risk of looking like I have no idea , anyone know what these dangling things might be from the tree next door Wonderingits something a little sinister. She added that the pods appeared to have spider webs around them, then shared a series of photographs to give people a better idea of what she was dealing with.And to her horror she was then told that the so-called pods were probably filled with around  baby spiders each.  Locals from the Sydney area began suggesting that the sacs could be the work of magnicent spiders or bolas spiders. One woman said the spiders were super cool and would parachute down with little parachute webs when the eggs hatch. But this did little to appease the mum, who wasnt impressed with the thought of spiders coming down onto the trampoline.  Despite the disturbing situation, the spiders should pose no threat to the woman according to the Australian Plants Society NSW.They said that magnicent spiders pose no threat to humans and revealed that the spindle-shaped egg sacs take several nights to construct. story: NewsAlarm clock saved couples flagging sex le - and now theyre closer than everSiobhan Wend realised her and her fiancé were spending too much time on their phones so took drastic actionShareCommentsByJane Lavender:,  FEB NewsAn alarm clock saved this couples relationship "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email Siobhan Wend and her fianceacute had hit some serious libido lows and werent sure what was to blame. Siobhans partner, as a working father, would often come home from work exhausted and turn to his phone for some horizontal bliss. story: NewsGeese and even boiled bats - some of the creatures to have fallen from the sky like Maltese fishPeople have been risking their lives to save the fish that have been falling from the sky in MaltaShareCommentsByMatt Roper:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news weird-news video massive-storm-causes-rain-fish-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:, combinedPrompt :true, subsets :[,,,,,],bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true,info:,article:,info:,],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:, combinedPrompt :true, subsets :[,,,,,],bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true""Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailResidents in Malta were left baffled when it started raining fish across the island. Gale-force gusts and heavy downpours, coupled with the rough seas, is believed to have caused the unusual phenomenon. The devastating storm has caused major damage and disruptions on the roads along the coastal area of the Mediterranean island. And the government issued a warning of high threat to le and property. But the gusts sent piles of sea bream flying off the sea and landed on the roads in Xemxija, near St Pauls Bay in north Malta.  A number of residents have been risking their lives to pick up the fish and collect them in piles. A man can be heard saying: One of the fish farms must have broke open, and theres hundreds and hundreds of fish that have been blown ashore, and these people are here picking up the fish from the middle of the street.But its not the first time people have looked up and found unusual things - from animals and fruit to cuts of meat - falling from the skies. Here are some of the others...Gone Geese  Over  geese suddenly fell from the sky during a thunderstorm above Idaho Falls, Idaho in April .Around  dead geese were found in a car park and  more on the top of a nearby warehouse. Mobile phone footage caught the moment the birds plummeted to the ground. Conservation officers determined that the birds were probably killed by one or more lightning strikes as they were flying. Jacob Berl said: “It’s just a freak accident.” Icy iguanas  It was so cold in Florida last year that it was literally raining frozen iguanas. Temperatures were so chilly in the Sunshine State it rained iguanas as the frozen lizards fell out of trees. The cold blooded lizards become sluggishthe temperature drops below C. And when the mercury fell to just C, the poor, frozen iguanas thudded out of their tree homes, unable to move.  Spider stormIn January last year spiders appeared to fall from the sky in Brazil’s southeast state of Minas Gerais.Videos posted onto social media showed screaming onlookers looking up to see hundreds of tiny black spiders rained down. In fact the arachnids were actually suspended in a huge web which has been spun to catch prey. The species of spider, known as parawixia bistriata, are known to make their webs high up. The web they spin is so fine it is nearly impossible to see with the naked eye, giving the impression the spiders are falling from the sky. Joatildeo Pedro Martinelli Fonseca, who recorded the phenomenon, said he was stunned and scared”. Flying Fish  Residents of Lajamanu, a remote desert town in Australia, saw hundreds of small white fish fall from rainclouds during two days in . Weather experts in Australia believe the fish, spangled perch, many of which were still alive, were sucked up in a thunderstorm and carried up to , feet up in the air before being dumped over the tiny town. And incredibly it wasn’t the first time - Lajamanu, which lies  miles from the nearest river, has reported being bombarded by falling fish twice before, in  and . One resident, Joe Ashley, , said: Usually fish are in the water and now they are falling out of the sky. Whatanything bigger falls out of the sky next  It could be crocodiles, that would be real scary. Flying before they can swim Tadpoles  Residents of Japan’s central Ishikawa prefecture were baffled in June  by the apparent downpour of tadpoles all around the coastal region. Clouds of dead tadpoles were reported falling from the sky in a number of cities, including Nanao where  tadpoles were found covering the windshields of cars in a  square metre area of a car park. Another dead tadpole downpour was reported by local officials  hours later in the city of Hankusan, in the same prefecture. Officials at Kanazawa Local Meteorological Observatory told local media that they were unsure how the tadpoles had arrived as there had been no reports of strong winds at the time. Winged Worms  In July , Eleanor Beal, a police department employee in Jennings, Louisiana, reported thousands of earthworms falling from the sky as she crossed the street to go to work. When I saw that they were crawling, I said, Its worms! Get out of the way! she told news channel WAFB. “Its very scary, Ive never seen anything like this in my le” Communications officer Martha Amie also witnessed the downpour, saying: “They were all over the street. I looked in the sky, there was no clouds, we werent under the poles and we werent under the trees and I couldnt believe it. “I just ran back inside because I didnt want any more to fall on my head.” Less than five miles away and about the same time, a tornado had touched down on a local river - which some believe may explain how the worms got into the air.an apple a day  A show of apples from rush-hour traffic to a halt in December  as the fruit rained down on car roofs and windscreens. The deluge left a -yeard stretch of the B strewn with green slush after the bizarre incident. One motorist, who was travelling with her husband, said: The apples fell out of nowhere. They were small and green and hit the bonnet hard. Everyone had to stop their cars suddenly. The phenomenon is believed to be down to a mini tornado which touched down where, sucking apples from the ground or from trees before travelling for miles and depositing the fruit over Coventry. Another theory is that the apples could have fallen from the hold of a plane. Bird invasion The largest recorded incident of dead birds falling from the sky occurred in Georgia in October . Over two nights at least , birds, made up of  dferent species, littered the runways at the Warner Robins Air Force base. Some believe these birds had all been caught in a lethal thunderstorm, then thrust into high altitudes by massive winds where some were unable to breathe and froze to death before raining down on the earth. Another theory is that the birds were disorientated by the air base’s bright lights, which they followed straight into the ground. Meat Mayhem  In what seems like something straight out of Cloudy With A Change of Meatballs, people in Kentucky witnesses huge chunks of fresh red meat falling from the clouds in . The meat showered down over a  yard long and  yard wide area, and each piece measured three to four inches long. On inspection the meat was identied as mutton, or possible venison, and contained muscle, lung and connective tissues. Although no conclusive explanation of the meat deluge has been found, some locals suggested a flight of well-fed buzzard had regurgitated their meal while flying above. Boiled bats  In January  hundreds of bats fell from the sky in Sydney, Australia, during a heatwave whilch boiled their brains. Most of the dead bats were babies, who are particularly susceptible to extreme heat. More than  of the bats were left scattered on the ground or hanging lelessly from trees as temperatures topped  degrees F . Kate Ryan, who manages the bat colony in Campbelltown, said: “They basically boil. It affects their brain – their brain just fries and they become incoherent. “It would be like standing in the middle of a sandpit with no shade.” Holy Cow

title: worlds smallest ever baby survives
story: NewsWorlds smallest ever baby SURVIVES after being born weighing less than lbThe boy, from Tokyo, Japan, is thought to be the smallest newborn boy ever to leave hospital in a healthy condition after he was born weighing just gShareCommentsByTanveer Mann:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB NewsThe child spent months in an incubator "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA miracle baby boy who was born weighing less than lb has finally gone home in a case thats made medical history. The tiny infant had to spend the first few months of his le in a hospital incubator. The boy, from Tokyo, is thought to be the smallest newborn boy ever to leave hospital in a healthy condition after he was born weighing just g . He was delivered at  weeks by emergency cesarean section in August after he stopped growing in the womb and doctors were concerned his le may be in danger. The baby was so small at birth, he could fit in cupped hands.   But after doctors at Keio Hospital managed his breathing and nutrition over several months, he grew to a healthy lbs and was able to be breastfed. He left the hospital last Wednesday, two months after his initial due date.  Now, the paediatricians who treated the newborn hope this case will give hope to other families of premature babies.Dr Takeshi Arimitsu told Kyodo News : I want people to know that babies canhome vigorous eventhey are born small. The record was previously held by a boy born in Germany in , weighing g , the hospital said, while the smallest girl was born weighing g , also in Germany, in . According to the Tiniest Babies Registry website, only  babies in the world have managed to survive after being born prematurely and weighing under g .

title: bbc should stop its glasgow bias and focus on dundee says homes under the hammer star martel maxwell
story: The BBC should look beyond Glasgow and focus more on Dundee, says Homes Under the Hammer presenter Martel Maxwell.The Dundonian was present at the launch party of the new BBC Scotland channel, which began this week.Martel believes the channel presents an opportunity to do things dferentlyShe wrote in her latest Tele column: #Of course Glasgow will feature more heavily on both ITV and BBC than other parts of the country, as perhaps it should, given it is our biggest city.#It’s also where BBC Scotland and STV have their HQs – and from a budget point of view, it costs more to set studios up or have entire crews travel where.#But bosses are aware Scotland as a whole has to be reflected back to licence payers. This is a chance not just to create jobs in the media, to make new stars and innovative programming it’s an opportunity to regularly visit all of Scotland.#Dundee has been under-represented on Scottish TV and that must change – to reflect not only the fact we are the fourth-largest citybut how great we look and how bright our future is.#If the Antiques Roadshow can do itBBC Scotland certainly can.#

title: blether celtic and arbroath man jimmy bone the hardest opponent
story: In a general conversation about football , I was asked which one player did I find it hard to play against.My answer was instant . . . Jimmy Bone.Now, my encounter was really brief, as I came on as a substitute for East Fe at Partick Thistle in , a game we were to lose -. In my time on the pitch, his movement was such I hadn’t encountered before, and he gave me “a doing”.Many years later, when he was assistant to Jocky Scott at Dens Park, I asked himhe remembered that game.“I do remember that game very well,” he immediately said.“I had just come back from injury at that time and was really buzzing to be back in the team.“I did give the East Fe central defenders a hard time.”Then, looking straight at me, he concluded: “Don’t worry, I would have given anyone a doing on that day.”After he scored well over  goals for Partick Thistle, others noted his form and he soon earned a move to Norwich, then on to Sheffield United.Celtic took him back to Scotland, but he didn’t appear regularly for the Hoops.In , Arbroath paid around £, to Celtic to bring him to Gayfield and then recouped treble that amount three years later when they sold him to Alex Ferguson’s St Mirren.After four years at Love Street, he had spells with Toronto Blizzard and Hong Kong Rangers before spending two years with Hearts and another stint at Arbroath.Bonemoved into management with Arbroath in that second spell, then took charge of Airdrie, St Mirren, East Fe and Stenhousemuir.In addition to his coaching stint at Dens, he enjoyed similar posts at Ross County, Partick Thistle and Chester City. Other appointments took him abroad to Zambiaand Bidvest Wits .

title: dundee announce pre contract signing of winger todd
story: Dundee have secured the summer signing of Queen of the South midfielder Josh Todd on a pre-contract deal.The -year-old impressed for the Doonhamers in the Championship as well as in their Scottish Cup victory over the Dark Blues last month.And Dens boss Jim McIntyre has moved quickly to secure the former St Mirren man on a two-year deal starting when his contract at Palmerston comes to an end this summer.Todd has scored six goals in  matches this season.Queens manager Gary Naysmith said: “I would like thank Josh for his efforts and contribution since joining the club.#He is a very talented player who has been great for us, it is disappointing to lose someone of his quality but that’s football.#We wouldn’t stand in the way of anyone who has the chance to move to a higher level, so he goes with our best wishes.#He is still with us for a wee while yet and, hopefully, he canfrom injury and play his part in helping us reach the play-offs.”

title: ewan gurr brexit polls suggest peoples vote would end with same result as first referendum
story: A fortnight ago, within  hours of one another, I had two encounters at opposite ends of the economic spectrum.The first was a breakfast gathering of a few hundred businessmen and women featuring the UK poll expert Professor John Curtice at Dundee’s Apex Hotel.The second was an afternoon at Dundee foodbank.However, what both experiences had in common was the topic of discussion – Brexit.Like a political prophet among men, Prof Curtice said he believed that the approaching prospect of a no-deal Brexit would lead to the fragmentation of the presiding UK Government – a statement that was given credence when it was revealed last week that up to  Cabinet resignations could followno deal goes ahead.He added: “The real question now is not what most people want but what most people are most willing to put up with.”On the unlikely prospect of a people’s vote, Prof Curtice said that there has been little movement between those who voted leave and remain, which suggests the likelihood of a dferent result could depend on whether eligible new voters registered and then turned out.However, he also said polls suggest a second referendum and a dferent outcome are both unlikely.

title: gordon forrest says dundee united fans vital in championship promotion push
story: Dundee United fans have been told they’re not just appreciated, they’ll be vital as the Championship promotion race reaches its climax.That’s the view of Tangerines assistant boss Gordon Forrest, who admits since ing to Scottish football last month he’s been blown away by the level of support Arabs give their team.Well over , headed for Falkirk on Saturday and, despite a small travelling support expected and the top two in the ision meeting in Dingwall, tonight’s clash with Inverness Caley Thistle at Tannadice will boast the biggest turnout in the second tier.While those kind of crowds can have a positive effect on the opposition, Gordon believes the positives of being the best-supported team in the ision easily outweigh any negatives.“The fans have been absolutely magnicent, particularly in the away games,” said the former Vancouver Whitecaps coach.“When the players are coming out for their warm-up, during the game, you can see the stands are packed. The fans are singing, they’re cheering and it just makes a massive dference for the players.“When we go back to Tannadice the noise levels there have been great. We appreciate it as a club and I know the players do.“When we play against teams they do pick up to their maximum in terms of their performance, they raise their game a little bit but it helps us in that push to pick up the points in the run-in.”Tonight, United will be without defender Freddy Frans after he had to come off with a groin injury at the weekend.He will see a specialist about the problem and, while United are hopeful he will not be out for too long, he has no chance of making tonight or Sunday, when the teamsto Tannadice to battle it out in the Scottish Cup quarter-finals.Rachid Bouhenna came on for Frans then had to go off late on with a facial injury, but could be OK.“Freddy is probably looking at a longer time out. In terms of finer detail and the number of days or weeks it’s hard to say just now,” added Gordon.“With Rachid, there was a lot of blood and a cut on the nose. You’ve got to be careful with that. Hopefully he can be patched up and be in the mix.”

title: sponsored 5 of the best chippies in scotland
story: Fish and chips have long-been a popular meal choice for those who want a tasty treat. In Scotland, we are incredibly lucky to have so many good quality fish and chip shops on our doorstep, many of them award-winning. Locally sourced produce is a big draw for fish and chip fans, but it is also the location, excellent customer service, and sustainability of these chippies that keep the customers coming back for more. Here we have selected five of the best chippies in Scotland for you to try# vw, px"  Cromars in St Andrews is a highly respected, award winning establishment, crowned Scottish Chip Shop of the Year  at the National Fish  Chip awards.Situated in St Andrews, in the heart of Scotland, Cromars is proud to serve homemade, quality plates of food to its customers every day. Steeped in Scottish history, St Andrews offers a stunning backdrop to the restaurant and takeaway with its winding cobbled streets and majestic sandstone buildings, and it is very proud to have been established in the town. Cromars is a venue where people of all ages can meet up and enjoy each other’s company.Being located in Scotland, Cromars only uses the finest and freshest local Scottish ingredients, its fish is expertly selected from JK Thomson Fish in Musselburgh, its langoustines are from St Monans, vegetables from Fe and potatoes from Super Fry in Musselburgh. Cromars believe in fresh food, handmade and expertly cooked in the best traditional way – which makes its fish and chips truly the best. Its food is made to order for every type of customer, choose to have your fish battered, breaded or grilled – the choice is yours!Once you visit Cromars you won’t want to go anywhere ! vw, px"  Scotland#s No. Fish and Chip Takeaway , Fochabers Fish Bar is a family-run traditional fish and chip shop situated in Moray  miles outside Elgin, serving the local community of Fochabers and surrounding areas.It prides itself on delivering the highest quality food cooked fresh to order, delivering excellent customer service and using only the finest produce available throughout the year.Fochabers Fish Bar is proud to be supplied with fresh haddock from Eat Mair Fish, Buckie, where all fish supplied is fully traceable and accountable. There are more than  Scottish vessels registered in the Seafish Responsible Fishing Scheme.Their potatoes are supplied by Wm Frasers of Aberdeen who source only the finest potatoes available on the market each week. They are prepared with love and care on Fochabers Fish Bar’s premises daily. Every potato is inspected by hand and any blemishes carefully removed before twice frying to ensure you receive the very best chips possible every day of the week.Quality, customer service, training and sustainability are at the heart of the business. vw, px"  Low’s Traditional Fish  Chips has been declared UK’s No. and Scotland’s No. in the National Fish  Chip Awards .The National Fish  Chip Awards aim to celebrate excellence among the UK’s fish and chip industry. With approximately , entrants, for Low’s to achieve Third Best in the Country is a fantastic achievement. They are assessed on sustainable sourcing, menu innovation, marketing, staff training, and most importantly, the quality of product and service provided to customers.Alex Walker of Low’s Traditional Fish and Chips in Westhill, was crowned nd in the UK and Best in Scotland in the Drywite Young Fish Frier of the Year Competition, part of the National Fish  Chip Awards.Marcus Coleman, chief executive at Seafish, who is behind the competition, said: “We’re extremely proud of Alex, who has showcased his skills and talent at every stage of the judging process.“He is the future of the fish and chip industry and we wish him all the very best of luck in the future.”Low’s is opening up a second business in Berryden Retail Park later this year. vw, px"  The Fish Works is a fish and chip takeaway located on the seafront in Largs, specialising in Scottish Seafood made to order.It has won many awards including: Winner of Best Fish and Chip Shop in Scotland and Best Newcomer at the Dine in Awards  Finalists at the National Fish  Chip Awards  Winner of Taste Our Best Award Scotland ,  and  Winner of a Green Tourism Award Winner of Best High-End Fish and Chip Takeaway at the Lux Food and Drink Awards  Finalist at the Scottish Entertainment Awards for Best Takeaway Regional Winner for West Coast of Scotland at the Scottish Food Awards and holder of the Fish and Chip Quality Award.The Fish Works is a family-run business run by husband and we team Ross and Tfany Irvin. They had the idea of bringing to Largs somewhere visitors and locals can come to enjoy fresh quality Scottish seafood in a relaxed environment with the best views of Firth of Clyde.The Fish Works is lucky to have access to the freshest local Scottish ingredients its fish is expertly selected from Peterhead by its Fish Merchant and its whole langoustines are landed daily in Largs. The ethos at The Fish Works is to give customers fresh food, handmade and expertly cooked in the best traditional way. vw, px"  Formerly a derelict Little Chef on the A in Tyndrum, The Real Food Café has been serving carefully and locally sourced homemade food in a relaxed environment since .The café has gathered a huge following over this time and attracts people from all corners of the world for its award-winning fish and chips. Located on the busy A trunk road in Tyndrum, the Real Food Café is the perfect halfway house when traveling through the West Highlands, whether it be for a freshly prepared coffee and homemade cake, warming soup on colder days or fish and chips whilst sitting outside on a warm summer’s day.There is good news for coeliac customers too – as the café has an ‘A’ grade accreditation from Coeliac UK for its gluten free offering, which includes fish and chips, so you can rest assured your meal will be prepared with great care.The café is a real living wage employer and this is reflected in the warm welcoming manner of the team. The café has its own EV rapid charger, bike racks for traveling guests and welcomes dogs.The café is currently committed to improving accessibility for disabled people, having recently put all of the team through a disability awareness course.
