title: Climate action call comes to Inverness streets
story: CLIMATE change activists from the Black Isle and Inverness have shown their solidarity for school pupils across the world after the youngsters held a lsquostrikersquo to flag up ecological concerns.New group Extinction Rebellion Highlands and Islands held a stall in Inverness High Streetlast Saturday, asking passers-by to sign a petition calling for urgent action by Highland Council to do its bit to tackle the threat, amid growing worries that the planetrsquos global warming is nearing an irreversible tipping point.Organised by Black Isle activist Anne Thomas, who is also involved with Transition Black Isle, the stall attracted  signatures in the space of  minutes.The youth strike, which included Highland participants, was sparked by Swedish teenager Greta Thunberg who spoke at the last major UN Climate Change summit saying adults were not doing enough and time was running out.ldquoLots of people had been impressed by the stand the kids had taken and were keen to show their support, said Ms Thomas. ldquoThey agreed that government at all levels is not doing enough to stop dangerous levels of global warming and climate change.ldquoScientists say we have less than  years to prevent warming going over . degrees, so we need to take drastic measures now. We could be on the brink of a mass extinction like the one which wiped out the dinosaurs.ldquoThe petition asked that the Highland Council... reverse inconsistent policies and work alongside the media to communicate with residents.The petition also called on the local authority to pass a climate emergency motion to make the region carbon neutral by .Fiona Cormie who has just taken on the role of co-ordinator of the group, said they hoped to add ldquosignicantly to its number of petition signatories in the coming weeks and present them to the council.Wednesday  Feb  : PM

title: Disaled workers getting a raw deal new report claims
story: MANY disabled people in Scotland have been ldquofrozen out of work due to their condition, according to research by disability charity Leonard Cheshire.Three out of four said they left their jobs because they had not received the support they needed to fulfil their role, and nearly one out of five who applied for a job in the past five years felt the employer had chosen not to consider them for the post because they had a disability.Kenny Shand from Inverness who found himself in this situation, said: ldquoNot everyone is treated with respect. Whether you have additional support needs or not, the system needs to be more transparent. Workplace adjustments donrsquot need to be expensive ndash they just need to be done.Stuart Robertson, director at Leonard Cheshire in Scotland, said the findings lt the lid on a ldquotough and unwelcoming employment landscape.He said: ldquoMost people with disabilities in  remain frozen out of the world of work. All of us must redouble our efforts to challenge outdated attitudes to disability and accelerate the positive change that enables everyone to thrive in the world of work.The research also suggests more than half of all managers consider the cost of workplace adjustments a barrier to employing people with disabilities.In more promising news, Leonard Cheshirersquos research found a fth of employers say they are more likely to employ someone with a disability.The charity said the latest research shows an increased awareness amongst employers of the UK Governmentrsquos Access to Work scheme giving people grant and other support based on their needs, is up to  percent in  from  percent in .But many recipients are waiting more than three months for their application to be approved and the charity wants government action.Wednesday  Feb  : PM

title: Family remember happy and friendly teenager after tragic accident near Inverness
story: The family of a teenager killed in a road traffic collision at Dochgarroch has spoken about their "happy-go-lucky boy who was always happy and friendly".Policehave confirmed that the -year-old who died as a result of the two-vehicle collision at around .pm on Sunday night was Samuel Foster, of Lochend near Inverness.The family said: ldquoSamuel, our darling boy, was incredibly popular and had a huge circle of friends. He attended Millburn Academy before moving to Inverness College two years ago to study engineering."He also worked at the bakery at Marks and Spencer for two years and loved his motocross biking and cars.ldquoSamuel was a happy-go-lucky boy who was always happy and friendly.ldquoSamuel was the youngest of four siblings and words canrsquot express how much he will be missed by his parents Heather and Lenny, his brother David and twin sisters Samantha and Kirsty, his nephew Reuben and niece Georgie.ldquoWe would like to thank the incredible number of people who have sent us messages of sympathy ndash your kind words mean so much and are a reminder of just how popular and well-loved Samuel was."We hope he will always be remembered this way.Wednesday  Feb  : PM

title: Funding blow to Highland food banks charity
story: North-based charity Blythswood Care has issued a public appeal for more donations after it lost an annual pound, recycling grant from Highland Council in the recent local authority budget.The charity which has one of the largest networks of food banks in the Highlands handles around  tonnes of clothing donations a year at its Evanton depot of which more than  per cent was reused or recycled.Previously the council financially supported the recycling work and some local authority properties already host textile banks for taking unwanted clothing deposits but this year withdrew support.The council had to plug an almost pound million financial hole in its budget amid shrinking government grants for core services, the moves was called a ldquobody blow by operations manager Ian Matheson who admitted the loss of the recycling grant is not a complete surprise.ldquoWe recognise that the Council has been faced with hard decisions. Wersquove enjoyed a mutually beneficial partnership with Highland Council for over  years and we really appreciate that, he said.ldquoTheir support has enabled us to develop our re-use and recycling activities, reducing waste, providing local employment and raising support for projects such as Blythswoodrsquos Highland Food Bank.ldquoDonations of clothing, bric-a-brac and quality furniture from the general public are going to be more important to us than ever as we aim to continue this aspect of our work despite the loss of this grant.The organisation processes more than , tonnes of donations a year at its Evanton depot, producing goods for its charity shops and selling on to processors in other parts of the country.Mr Matheson said ldquoWe have to constantly review all that we do and consider what efficiencies we can make. You can help us now by giving our shops your custom and donations.ldquoAll donations will be gratefully received so we can have continuity of employment ndash because this is about jobs too ndash as well as maintain service provision.A council spokeswoman said: ldquoWe have had very positive discussions with Blythswood and these are ongoing about how we can possibly work together in the future.Blythswood welcomes donations of textiles, footwear, bric-a-brac, small electrical goods, books and good quality furniture.Wednesday  Feb  : PM

title: Highland Council investing extra in roads maintenance
story: Highland Council is hoping an additional pound. million for maintenance announced as part of this yearrsquos budget will make a ldquonoticeable dference across the region.The funding, approved as a priority area for the revenue budget, will be shared out across Highland with area committees able to decide how to prioritise it more locally.Chairman of the councilrsquos environment, development and infrastructure committee, Councillor Allan Henderson, said: ldquoWe have the most extensive network of roads in the UK and, added to this, we are faced with some of the most severe weather conditions in the Highlands.ldquoThe freeze-thaw conditions in particular cause immense damage to road surfaces and this is very evident in the past few weeks.ldquoRoad conditions are a high priority for local residents and this was very clear in our recent engagement with communities and local representatives.ldquoThe additional resource will, I hope, make a noticeable dference and can be allocated to the roads with the most urgent need of repairs, right across the Highlands.Area allocations based on road mileage and population are:Badenoch  Strathspey: pound, Caithness: pound,Inverness: pound, Lochaber: pound, Nairn: pound,Ross  Cromarty: pound,Isle of Skye: pound,Sutherland: pound,Wednesday  Feb  : PM

title: Historic Inverness city centre mosaics almost completed
story: FINAL measurements have been taken for the re-installation of a well-known Inverness mosaic.Restoration work to breathe le into the historic mosaics in Invernessrsquos Academy Street started in July last year.It came after Cairngorm Taverns secured an Inver-ness Townscape Heritage grant to fully restore the former AI Welders building, which is set to have a street-level bar and first-floor restaurant.It appointed conservation specialist Laing Traditional Masonryas its main contractor although the first phase of work has been handled by sub-contractor the Mosaic Restoration Company .The mosaic of welders and foundry men at work was partially taken down last year by Northamptonshire-based MRC. Mosaics have been taken to MRCrsquos factory for restoration ndash and as one of the four original mosaics was missing, the firm has used a photograph from the s to recreate the original design.MRCrsquos Gary Bricknell described it as a fascinating project for the family-run firm and he looks forward to putting the work back in place next month.ldquoItrsquos been an really interesting job, he said. ldquoEvery one of the tiles is hand-cut for these arches which are about four or five square metres. Wersquove used tens of thousands of tiles and wersquove been working on it for over six months now.Inverness Townscape Heritage Project provided a pound, grant towards the restoration of the B-listed building which is set to open in September as a showcase for Cairngorm and Loch Ness breweries.Sam Fairclf, managing director at Cairngorm Brewery which is involved with Cairngorm Taverns, said: ldquoWe are looking to showcase as much Highland produce as possible.The building was originally the head office of the Rose Street Foundry and Engineering Company and changed to AI Welders in the s.This project is the first major investment by the Inverness Townscape Heritage Project, which is a partnership regeneration project focusing on Academy Street.The refurbishment is a collaboration of funding partners including Inverness City Heritage Trust , Historic Environment Scotland and the Heritage Lottery Fund.Alison Tanner of ICHT said: ldquoThis is not just an interesting project, it is specialist restoration, repair and reinstatement work and needs to be rejoiced.ldquoIt has been years in the planning, the local public are passionate about the mosaics and the building as a whole and this work will save them for future generations.Wednesday  Feb  : PM

title: Hotel plan for Inverness car park site
story: PLANS which would see a city centre car park transformed into a six-storey hotel have been unveiled.The pound million proposal by developer SRP Inverness Ltd was displayed to the public at the Spectrum Centre on Farraline Park, immediately next to the two-deck Rose Street car park which is earmarked as the site for the -metre high hotel.The proposal is the latest city hotel development from SRP Inverness directors Stewart Campbell and Stuart McCaffer, who were also behind the creation of the Inverness Encore Hotel, now the Pentahotel, on nearby Academy Street.Mr Campbell is confident the -bedroom L-shaped building will attract interest from a globally-known hotel brand, bringing something new to the Inverness accommodation mix.ldquoWe have worked with a number of global brands over the years, he said.ldquoInverness has massive global tourism and a lot of people, particularly global travellers, want the comfort of a well-known global brand.ldquoInverness is a strong tourism market, but therersquos been a lack of supply over the years. Other than the Travelodge on Academy Street in , there hasnrsquot been a new hotel built in Inverness since .The proposal includes a gym, three retail units within the hotel footprint and parking for  cars.Mr Campbell believes the hotel will benefit from its proximity to Inverness bus and railway stations, while any under capacity at the car park would be compensated by the nearby multi-storey car park.Mr Campbell and Mr McCaffer also own the neighbouring Rose Street Hall, which they hope to utilise for retail or restaurant use once the hotel is completed.Between the two, they also plan to construct a new bus and taxi road, replacing the footpath linking the bus station and Rose Street retail units.SRP Inverness expects to apply for planning permission in mid-April.Wednesday  Feb  : PM

title: Inverness MP calls for cross party approach to secure post Brexit funding
story: INVERNESS MP Drew Hendry has issued a cross-party rally cry ahead of Brexit.He has written to the Scotland spokespeople of each of the main political parties urging them to put pressure on the UK government to prevent Scotland losing out on millions of pounds in EU funding,the UK leaves the EU.Mr Hendry, the SNPs business spokeman, has called on parties to work together to ensure the UK government delivers a like-for-like replacement for vital EU development funds in the event of Brexit.Mr Hendry said: ldquoCommunities across Scotland would be hit hard by the loss of millions of pounds in vital EU fundingthe UK government drags us out of the EU against our will."The best way to protect this funding is for Scotland to remain in the EU - as we voted overwhelmingly for - butBrexit does go ahead then the UK government must commit to replacing every single penny of the funding Scotland stands to lose."It is shocking that the UK government has already broken its own word, and failed to consult on detailed plans to replace the lost EU funding and the huge benefits it brings for Scotland.ldquoIn addition to the many other benefits of our EU membership, Scotland has enjoyed huge investment in jobs, communities and infrastructure from European funds. It is vital that this investment continues like-for-like, and that the Scottish Government continues to oversee the funding so it meets Scotlands needs.ldquoAt present, groups across the country need to make decision about their future, but have no idea what sort of funding will be available after . This must not be another power grab away from the Scottish Parliament.ldquoSome of this funding helps level the playing field of regional inequality, which is stark when comparing rural areas with urban parts. The Tories must be held to account, investment levels must be matched, and clarity must be given to communities across Scotland.ldquoThe UK government cannot continue to kick this issue into the long grass and weasel out of their responsibilities. It is time for MPs and MSPs of all parties to demand that this money is protected in full and in time to give certainty to communities across Scotland."Wednesday  Feb  : PM

title: Rethink on Inverness city centre revamp
story: COUNCIL officers are to go back to the drawing board amid concerns over an ambitious project which aims to transform a key area in Inverness city centre.A bold vision including wider pavements and reduced traffic speeds in Academy Street was unveiled in November at the start of a public consultation.The Accessing Inverness project aims to complement a pound million upgrade of the rail station plus a revamp of the Victorian Market and involves HiTrans, the regional transport partnership for the Highlands and Islands, Highland Council and other organisations.Although the project team wants to apply for Sustrans funding to take the project to the next stage, Inverness councillors have demanded further work, including an impact an assessment for people with disabilities.It follows concerns that removing light and sound-controlled pedestrian crossings plus making the street and pavements the same level will pose dangers to visually impaired people.Inverness Ness-side councillor Ron MacWilliam described the design and report presented to councillors as ldquoflawed and said something had to happen.ldquoNumber one is making sure people who are least able to navigate their way around the streets of Inverness are considered in any design, he said.ldquoI donrsquot think people who are blind or partially-sighted have been considered.Accessing Inverness team leader Fiona McInally stressed there was more work to be done but the deadline for the funding application was April .She said the proposed design was outline only.ldquoIt is not set in stone, she said. ldquoWe are trying to get to a position we can get a solution and go forward.Inverness Provost Helen Carmichael said people had been asking for improvements for years and there was now an opportunity which must not be missed.Wednesday  Feb  : PM

title: Roads not safe for city cyclists says Inverness campaigner
story: A LOT needs to be done to bring roads in Inverness up to a standard that makes them safe and easy for road users to navigate, a leading cycling campaigner has said.Brian MacKenzie, convener of the Highland Cycle Campaign, said: ldquoI cycle a lot and there is no doubt the roads in the town are in very poor condition.ldquoThe trunk roads, too, need attention.Championing the cause for better and safer routes for cyclists he said drivers also need to be aware of cyclists and give greater consideration to them.ldquoDrivers often criticise cyclists when they see them weaving along certain routes but often they are doing that simply to avoid potholes and are taking evasive action, he said.ldquoAt the Raigmore Interchange, on the ramp joining the A south from the A, there is a pothole which has been there for some time. It is now gathering water and there is a warning sign for traffic alerting them to flooding.ldquoThere are also two more long potholes which are much more dangerous for cyclists and motorists just as you enter the interchange off the northbound ramp, coming from the Beechwood direction of the A.ldquoThe seal between the interchange and the ramp has gone andyou are cycling along there on a dark night you canrsquot see it, so your wheel can get caught up in it. These are like tram lines and they could throw you off a bike and cause serious injury.ldquoEvery vehicle coming from the A has to go across these potholes as they enter the interchange as well and they have been like that for a considerable time.ldquoI am wondering when the trunk roads people are going to carry out these repairs.While Highland Council is responsible for the upkeep of most roads in Inverness and the surrounding towns and villages, Bear Scotland is responsible for trunk roads.A spokesman for the organisation told the Courier last week that major defects, including deeppotholes which could pose a danger to road users, are repaired within  days, with safety inspections of all roads under its care inspected on a weekly basis.Wednesday  Feb  : PM

title: Stonework to be refurbished at Invernesss Victorian Market
story: Stonework at the Academy Street entrance to Invernesss Victorian Market is to be refurbished at a cost of pound,.The sum will be coveredby grants from the Academy Street Townscape Heritage Trust andInverness Common Good Fund .The decision to push ahead with the project will mean a delay to other planned mechanical and electrical works, alongwith the installation ofnew doors at the market.pound, remains allocated towards the upgrading of shopfronts at the market, including new lighting and flooring.Wednesday  Feb  : PM

title: Success sees Inverness Town House tours extended
story: POPULARITY has prompted the number of guided tours of Inverness Town House to double this summer.City councillors have agreed to add two more tours each week after positive feedback.The tours were introduced in June in a move which completed a so-called cultural triangle which includes the cityrsquos museum and Inverness Castle Viewpoint.Two tours on Thursdays have been run by High Le Highlandand proved logistically and financially viable ndash making a pound. profit ndash with the additional two tours on Tuesdays starting on from May .Tours have not disrupted any business in the building and visitors have found them engaging, informative and entertaining.Inverness provost Helen Carmichael said: ldquoWell done to High Le Highland and in particular their team of guides, who helped the council create a third, new, visitor attraction in the town house, which along with the museum and art gallery and castle viewpoint have created an accessible lsquocultural trianglersquo around the Castle Wynd area.ldquoAs we move towards the redevelopment of Inverness Castle as a new lsquomust-seersquo visitor attraction, the Town House Tours will complement the tourism offering in this city centre location.HLH chief executive Ian Murray said: ldquoHigh Le Highland has been delighted to work with the council to create public access to the splendid town house and we look forward to seeing visitor numbers and tour provision increasing this summer.Wednesday  Feb  : PM

title: reds boss not surprised by move for rival
story: Dons boss Derek McInnes insists it is no surprise Celtic’s Brendan Rodgers became a wanted man in the English top flight after the double-treble.Rodgers has joined Premier League Leicester City as replacement for Claude Puel who was sacked by the Foxes on Sunday.Celtic reluctantly agreed to let their manager talk to Leicester having reached a potential compensation package of £ million.Rodgers won all seven domestic honours available to him since taking charge at Parkhead in .McInnes has been Rodgers’ main challenger during his time in Scotland and lost out to his Hoops side in three domestic finals.Under McInnes, Aberdeen also finished runners-up in both seasons Rodgers led the Parkhead side to the Premiership title.Rodgers was on course for another league title as Celtic are currently eight points ahead of second-placed Rangers.Chances of an historic treble-treble were still alive as Celtic remain in the Scottish Cup and are set to face Hibs in the quarter-finals on Saturday.McInnes said: “ You are never totally surprised because Brendan is a very good manager.“And when very good managers are doing well they are going to be linked with other jobs.“I am pretty sure that the timing is not ideal for Brendan as like any manager he would probably want to do these things at the end of the season.“There is no doubt that he has earned the right to have a decision to make. We wish him well.”Rodgers’ shock exit has caused seismic repercussions within Scottish football.Celtic are eight points clear at the table but, minus Rodgers, rivals could suddenly be invigorated at the chance of a late Premiership title battle.Former Parkhead boss Neil Lennon has come in as a replacement until the end of the season.He has started immediately, as Celtic travel to face Hearts tonight.Lennon led Celtic to three league titles and two Scottish Cups during his time as manager before leaving in .He was a free agent having left Hibs last month – ironically the club Celtic face at the weekend.The Hoops’ next home game is against Aberdeen on Premiership action next Saturday.McInnes insists the situation at Celtic will have no repercussions for his own team.Askedthe situation offered hope to clubs like Aberdeen, he said: “It doesn’t give us any more hope.“We just have to deal with what we have to deal with.“It is always for us just trying to win and compete and nothing changes regardless of who is in charge at other clubs.”The English top flight does not represent unknown territory to Rodgers as he guided Swansea to promotion to the Premier League.In their first season the Swans finished th.At the end of that term Rodgers moved to Liverpool. In his second season at Anfield under his guidance Liverpool launched a serious title bid and were top of the table late on.However, slip-ups against Cha and Crystal Palace saw Liverpool miss out on a first league title since .Rodgers was sacked by ’Pool in October .However, his appointment by Celtic the next summer was seen as a major coup.McInnes said: “We said when Brendan came into the Scottish game he was a calibre of manager with the experience at a level that can only be a positive for the game.“He has backed that up.“Brendan was a brilliant ambassador for the Scottish game and has done the job that was asked of him and a bit more.”

title: big parents evening to sell apprentice benefits
story: An Aberdeen business group is set to host what is being billed as Scotland’s biggest parents’ evening.Parents and carers are invited to the free event, hosted by school and business link organisation Developing the Young Workforce North East.The event will explain the dferences between the three types of Scottish apprenticeships: foundation, modern and graduate.The event will take place at the Aberdeen and Grampian Chamber of Commerce on March  from .-pm.The evening is part of the city’s Scottish Apprenticeship week activities.The week was established to show the benefits of having apprenticeships for those who wish to become one, as well as the firms who offer them.There are more than , people in Scotland who work as apprentices in a range of careers, from digital technologies to social care.Councillor John Wheeler, education operational delivery convener, said: “There are a iety of apprenticeships available, including foundation courses which pupils can undertake while still at school.“Aberdeen City Council is committed to ensuring our young people have the best possible outcomes in le and our schools are helping to promote Scottish Apprenticeship Week.“Events such as this provide parents and carers with an insight into the potential opportunities for their children to develop their skills and secure rewarding employment.“I would encourage as many people as possible to attend.”

title: ayr rugby club near move
story: NewsAyr Rugby Club near move to new town centre base at Dam Park as they prepare to sell Millbrae homeThe Millbrae men, who top the Tennents Premiership, are in advanced talks to sell their Millbrae home and move to Dam Park in Ayr town centre.ShareByStuart Wilson:,  OCT NewsDam Park could play host to Ayr Rugby Club as soon as  "Get the biggest daily stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailBooming Ayr Rugby Club are nearing a deal to sell their Millbrae home and move to the town centre. Plans to buy council-owned Dam Park are at an advanced stage. The club, currently top of the Tennent’s Premiership, hope the bold switch will take them to the next level. Ayr would earn a multi-million pound jackpot by hiving off their own land for housing, with builder Cala Homes believed to be preferred bidder for the site. And they plan to use part of the cash for a pound, synthetic surface to be laid at their new home. Club chiefs have spent the last year in talks over a move and hope to seal the deal soon.  If the switch is rubber-stamped by South Ayrshire Council Ayr could be playing out of Dam Park as early as . One source said: “It is the move that makes sensethe club is to continue growing. “Next season sees the start of the Super Six set-up with games to be broadcast live on television. “It is potentially a great  for Ayr and bringing the club into the heart of the town can benefit so many.” The switch would see Ayr Seaforth Athletic Club on the move to a new sporting centre planned for Craigie. And junior side Whitletts Victoria couldto the heart of their community with a revamp of the old activity complex on the cards. Ayr rugby supremo Billy McHarg said talks on the move are progressing well.  He said: “Discussions to this point have been positive. “We’re keen to work with all parties to find the right solution and one which will benefit the whole town. “We feel that Ayr Rugby Club coming into the town centre would be a big step forward.” Club members would still have to approve such a move. Ayr have been at scenic Millbrae since . Prior to that they played out of Newton Park, Dam Park, the Old Racecourse and King George V playing fields. Whitletts chairman John Dalton said: “Talks have been very positive and we are currently looking at alternative options. “The football park at Whitletts is the obvious route to go down and would represent ahome to our roots. “A lot of water is still to go under the bridge but as Ayr’s junior football club we are viewing this as a positive opportunity.” Craigie councillor Ian Cavana said: “It may be that a deal is close but nobody will be moving anywhere until the new sports centre at Craigie is up and running. “Work is due to start on that next summer and that’s when we should see real progress.” A council spokesman said: “Discussions on the future of Dam Park are ongoing.”Like us on FacebookFollow us on TwitterDaily NewsletterTheScottishDailyRecordFollow @Daily_RecordSubscribe to our Daily newsletterEnter emailSubscribeMore OnSouth Ayrshire CouncilAyr NewsAyrAyr Rugby

title: hourstons closes ayr last independent
story: NewsHourstons closes in Ayr as last independent department store shuts up shop todayThe last independent bastion of the High Street is closing today with a giant clear-out taking place.ShareByStephen Houston:,  FEB NewsLeg-end - show is over for Hourstons "Get the biggest daily stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailAyr’s last independent department store closes at pm tonight – but not before a giant clear-out. General manager Linda Lawson will pay tribute to  staff, who are all losing their jobs. And absolutely everything that could earn a pound was sold – including old mannequins , fashion stands and even store room shelving. The massive clear-out included giving away box loads of coat hangers. The building closes after  years of trading after current multi-millionaire owners the Jebreel family pulled the rug. As stock was snapped up in the sale, staff turned to fixtures and fittings to sell. Eight mannequins at pound each were snapped up - and some will remain gracing town windows. The building itself is now up for sale at offers over pound, but it is impossible to think it will ever operate as a single unit again. Staff are wanting to bow out quietly and didn’t want to line-up for an official “last photo” for the Ayrshire Post. MSP John Scott described the loss to the town as a “hammer blow.” Hourstons – and then Arnotts under House of Fraser control – has been one of Ayr’s retail institutions since the s. Orcadian David Hourston first opened a shop in Kyle Street before building the present store in . On David’s death in , his sons took over the business which had become one of the largest retail drapery establishments in Scotland. Its tearooms, smoking rooms and roof gardens became famed across the country. In April  the business was acquired by the House of Fraser group and in the years following, ious changes took place, both in nameand in ownership. Hourstons Ltd was formed in  by Isaac and Helen Jebreel of Hampstead, London. The store’s Facebook site says: “Hourstonshas been a retail beacon on the high street for generations, everyone has a story or memory in connection with the place” Shoppers shared their memories on its Facebook site this week. Sharon Johnstone said: “My uncle Bob was your restaurant manager years ago. “There was the wee lady in the lt, Santa, and many more lovely memories. “Hourstons will never be forgotten as long as there are mums and grannys still saying, “look at the state of you, I couldn’t dress you in Hourstons window!”Like us on FacebookFollow us on TwitterDaily NewsletterTheScottishDailyRecordFollow @Daily_RecordSubscribe to our Daily newsletterEnter emailSubscribeMore OnFacebookLawsonAyrSocial mediaAyr News

title: hydro power set earn cash
story: NewsHydro power set to earn cash from the River AyrA water-driven turbine is set to generate power from river flowShareByStephen Houston:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB NewsWeve got the power - how the turbine will operate "Get the biggest daily stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA cash generating hydro turbine delayed for more than three years seems set to happen at last. The pound million screw will be positioned right on the old mill weir on the River Ayr opposite Ayrshire College. The weir originally drove an old cornmill on the site. Now tens of thousands of pounds a year will be generated by the flow of the river. Updated plans are now being considered by South Ayrshire Council, which is behind the scheme through the local Energy Agency. They show a single archimedes screw turbine at the old Nethermills Weir. Consultants Mann Power Hydro say: “Completion of this project will create a supply of renewable energy into the local distribution network, proposing firstly to sell the majority of output locally to meet the electricity demands of Ayrshire College, where the grid connection will be made. “In mitigation, the project includes a historic improvement to the passage of eels, lampreys and salmon smolts at the weir by the provision of new specialised passes for these species, and also improves upstream and downstream migration for salmon and other fish species. “It will moderate the flows into the existing passes in some conditions, which will make these less challenging. “This will help ameliorate a general problem whereby a weir is a barrier to migration of fish.” It is predicted the turbine - more than  feet in diameter and  feet long - will generate up to  kilowatts per year. The blade will turn at a maximum  revolutions per minute The Energy Agency carried out a study last year to estimate the energy potential passing over the weirs at Nethermills. It is expected the council will pocket pound, a year from selling the power and the scheme would receive a pound, feed-in-tarf. The single four-bladed screw is enough to power  homes. A report said: “With proper maintenance the scheme should continue to generate clean power for many decades after its capital cost has been repaid. “The scheme would provide an eye-catching and interesting landmark in the middle of the town, an emblem of the community’s dedication to the principle of sustainable development. A decision on approval is expected shortly.Like us on FacebookFollow us on TwitterDaily NewsletterTheScottishDailyRecordFollow @Daily_RecordSubscribe to our Daily newsletterEnter emailSubscribeMore OnSouth Ayrshire CouncilAyrAyr NewsEnvironmentScottish rivers

title: scotlands king cone philip mancini
story: NewsScotlands "King Cone" Philip Mancini scoops Ice Cream Alliances national contestDessert guru wins first place for his blackcurrant sorbetShareByGary Fanning:,  FEB News"Get the biggest daily stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailScotland’s“King Cone” has licked the opposition again. Philip Mancini won first place for his blackcurrant sorbet dessert in the Ice Cream Alliance’s national contest. The dessert guru, who runs Mancini’s Ice Cream in Ayr, has already been crowned UK champion ice cream maker three times and won numerous awards for his products over the years. Philip said: “I’m always delighted to win these ICA awards as you’re competing against the very best in the business. “It comes after a great year for Mancini’s and the industry as a whole. “A great summer like we had in  is always good news for us and we’ve an exciting  ahead too.” The latest success marks the start of what Philip hopes will be a new chapter in his ice cream dynasty as he prepares to open a beach-front cafe in Prestwick in April. Philip said: “I told my family I was going to spend more time on the golf course . “But I can’t stay away from ice cream. “I put our success down to Italian flavours combined with the best quality Scottish dairy products and generations of experience handed down from father to son.” As well as the new cafe, the grandfather-of-three looks set for a record year supplying romance-themed ices to wedding across Scotland. The specialist treats include Jamaican Me Crazy, made with exotic fruits, a strawberry and prosecco sorbet and an alluring dark chocolate and raspberry creation. The ICA National Ice Cream Competition recognises the best manufacturers and vendors from across the UK and Ireland.
