title: Iain Macwhirter  Get over it - cis women are just on the wrong side of history
story: This, apparently, is to educate heteronormative women about their ldquoprivilege ndash the fact that they can use the toilets, sorry ldquowashrooms, of their choice and access healthcare. Irsquom not sure who exactly has been preventing transgender women using public conveniences. So far as I know, you donrsquot have to show a birth certicate, or undergo a medical exam to have a pee. But what do I know as a pale, stale male.What I do know is that ldquocis-gender is an ugly neologism which many women find offensive. They are content with their present sexual terminology. ldquoCis is in the same linguistic ballpark as ldquoTERF ndash trans exclusionary radical feminist, which is a term of abuse used against women who believe persons with penises are, er, male. I should be careful here because a number of TERFS have been banned from social media for saying that a person with a penis is a man. So I wonrsquot say that.Instead, letrsquos just take it as read that in future we are going to have to accept that the concept of sexual dferentiation with which we have been living for thousands of years is finally being exposed as a malign transphobic hood. At any rate, the Scottish Government appears determined to press ahead with reform of the Gender Recognition Act, which will allow trans people to assign themselves legally and biologically female. Hitherto, trans people have had to undergo medical examination and get a diagnosis of ldquogender dysphoria. No more. From now on, anyone can change their birth certicate to whatever they wish.Earlier this month, Holyroodrsquos culture committee warned that ending binary ldquoMale or Female questions in the Scottish census will render much of the results meaningless and, willy nilly, import an unscientic definition of sex into the law. But the Scottish Government is not listening. Nicola Sturgeon told a UN equalities conference last week that the concerns of feminists about the GRA are ldquomisplaced.Women ndash sorry, ldquomenstruators ndash who say that self-ID erases their sexual identity will be told: just get over it. They can complain that ldquosex is a protected characteristic under the  Equalities Act, and that women therefore have a right to their own unique spaces. But now that men can actually become women under the law, this right will be impossible to articulate. Trans women with male anatomy will be entitled to enter womenrsquos changing rooms, girl guide troops or womenrsquos prisons. Women who complain will be guilty of transphobia, and are likely to be visited by the police recording a ldquohate incident.Now, I have nothing against adults changing their gender, or identying as women, queer, non-binary, intersex or whatever. It seems to be reinforcing outmoded concepts of gender to suggest that, because someone wants to wear dresses, play with dolls and put on makeup, they must have a lady brain in a male body. I thought we had left pink-for-girls gender stereotyping behind. But never mind. No-one wishes trans people any ill ndash certainly not me. But now that we are abandoning the very biological definition of sex, there are some anomalies that need to be addressed.Last week, a British transgender man, who had IVF by sperm donation and gave birth, won a court battle to prevent his child having ldquomother on its birth certicate. It will be the first child in history to have no mother. The The AIRE Centre, a human rights charity, contested this on the grounds that it would make le dficult for the child in future, when they apply for visas or anything which enquires about family background. The Government said simply that this isnrsquot a problem. From now on, fathers can give birth ndash end of.But Irsquom not sure this is the end of the matter. Children have not been included in the gender recognition debate thus far, even though they have rights too. It could be psychologically disturbing for a child to find, one day, that its mother has decided to become its dad. That song ldquoSometimes I feel like a motherless child takes on a whole new meaning.Of course, the trans parent will still be present, but is it OK to expect a child to suddenly start calling her natural mother her father  I would have thought that a child has a continuing right to a legal motherthey were born with one. If misgendering a trans person is unacceptable, surely demothering a child should be too. This is going to be confusing to say the least.Then there is the question of sport. The controversy over athlete Caster Semenya, a woman with high testosterone, raises the question of how to regard trans womenrsquos participation in women-only sport. Athletes who have testes, and therefore posses greater body mass, muscle strength and bone density, have an unfair advantage over old-fashioned women who have genetically female bodies.Next week, the International Association of Athletics Federations will argue in a hearing in Switzerland that people like Semenya should take testosterone-suppressing drugs before competing. Not only would this drive a coach and horses through the anti-doping protocols, it surely poses problem for transgender athletes who, of course, also take drugs like testosterone to help them transition to their ldquocorrect male sex. I hope the sporting authorities can get their heads around that because I canrsquot.Yet this is a very live issue in many sports. In the US, the ban on trans women taking part in power-lting events is being lted to prevent accusations of discrimination. You might have thought that having beefy, male-bodied women participating in these contests is discriminating against women athletes. Though, of course, only transphobes would say that, so we wonrsquot go there.The logical solution to this conundrum is to end sexual segregation in sport. Andwomen who are born biologically female never win any medals, tough. Strangely, there doesnrsquot seem to be the same issue about female-bodied trans men participating in male-only sport . Irsquom sure that has nothing whatever to do with the fact that they wonrsquot win anything.So welcome to the brave new world of post-sexual dferentiation, where men become women and fathers have children. It is one of the most radical and abrupt cultural changes in human history.Women have had a pretty bad deal in previous centuries, when they were regarded often as chattels without rights. In some Muslim societies theyrsquore still second-class citizens. Now, as women are finally emerging from the shadow of patriarchy, they are being told, by men, that they no longer have exclusive rights to their sexual identity.Itrsquos a weird turn of events. It seems women are just on the wrong side of history. But somehow, I donrsquot think theyrsquoll go quietly.

title: Marianne Taylor  Last chance for Mundell to put country before party
story: The majority of these demands are perfunctory, of course, made in the knowledge and expectation that they will be ignored by the target, while playing well with the initiatorrsquos supporters.The craziness of the last few months has precipitated a flurry of genuine and warranted resignation demands, however, which under normal political circumstances would have resulted in multiple ministerial heads rolling in any other era the Prime Minister would have been forced out long ago.Marianne Taylor: BBC is better off without Neil and HumphrysAnother case in point is Scottish Secretary David Mundell, whose stubborn insistence on being ineffectual in the face of the biggest crisis this country has faced in generations is matched only by that of Jeremy Corbyn. Mr Mundellrsquos wan smiles and empty words about doing the best for Scotland as the Government he is a member of readies itself to push us off the no-deal Brexit clf, is as astonishing as it is appalling. He, too, should have gone months ago, not least over the manner in which his party has arrogantly steamrollered over the views and interests of the country he supposedly represents.Read more: Mundell should resign there is no-deal BrexitRemarkably still in post, Mr Mundell now has one last chance to make a meaningful contribution to the ridiculous and dangerous situation the Westminster parliament has created for itself. The SNP is right to call for Mr Mundell to show some mettle and make clear that he will not serve in a Government that is willing to take us out of the European Union without a deal, a situation that would put the already fragile Scottish economy on the road to ruin. As the Scottish Secretary is well aware, businesses will fail, jobs will be lost and real people will suffer the sort of real hardships that will be dficult to recover from.Marianne Taylor: BBC is better off without Neil and HumphrysSNP Westminster leader Ian Blackford has written to Mr Mundell, laying out the gravity of the situation and calling on him to back growing cross-party demands to halt the Brexit process by extending Article  and making clear to his boss, Theresa May, that he will resign unless she faces up the extremists in her party and takes no-deal off the table.At this critical juncture, the least that the people of Scotland deserve from the man who represents them at Cabinet level is honesty about where his loyalties lie: will he put country or party first  Mr Mundell, it really is that simple.Read more: Mundell should resign there is no-deal BrexitOf course, Mr Blackfordrsquos letter also highlights the bleakness of the dilemma facing the SNP. If Mrs May gets her way and Parliament is faced with a last-minute binary choice between her terrible deal - which deprives us of the key benefits being in the EU - and an even more catastrophic no-deal, it leaves the party in a dficult position. How should Nicola Sturgeon instruct her MPs to vote in this scenario  Backing Mrs Mayrsquos ldquomy way or the highway deal would be criticised by many as a U-turn of epic proportions and a sign of weakness. Not voting for it, and thus facilitating a no-deal Brexit, would likely be viewed by many voters as unforgivable, leaving the party open to allegations that this is the outcome it has been secretly hoping for all along, in order to boost support for independence.Ms Sturgeon and her colleagues will be hoping the growing number of Tory ministers and backbench MPs ndash including Cabinet secretaries Amber Rudd, Greg Clarke and David Gauke - poised to revolt against their leader should she refuse to rule out a no-deal Brexit, will come to their rescue in the frantic days and weeks to come.Marianne Taylor: BBC is better off without Neil and HumphrysThe emergence of the The Independent Groupmay also end up helping the SNPrsquos predicament, at least in the short term. Formed last week when eight MPs resigned from Labour unhappy at Mr Corbynrsquos disastrous leadership, it did not initially appear to be an important development. But when three Tory MPs also resigned and joined up, using the moment to launch a blistering attack on Mrs Mayrsquos disastrous Brexit strategy and their partyrsquos lurch to the right, it started to feel more signicant.What binds these MPs from dferent sides of the House of Commons is dismay at the drt of both parties to the extremities. And despite not being a proper party - yet - or having any actual policiesit seems many voters quite like what they see.Read more: Mundell should resign there is no-deal BrexitMomentum has grown over the weekend, with polls already putting the group on  per cent, just one behind the increasingly irrelevant Lib Dems.Many are asking whether TIG has a future. Surely, however, whatrsquos most important is the future of the country, andthis new movement serves only to facilitate the halting of Article , so that a new road out of the current mess can be found, then it will already have done more for the UK than Mr Corbyn. Or indeed Mr Mundell for that matter.

story: The Scottish Labour leader saidit came to a vote, he would support Remain.THE SNP said the remark would "utterly dismay" many Labour supporters.Labour MP Ian Murray also criticised Mr Leonard, saying his position would disappoint party members, as there was"no good Brexit".Mr Leonard also suggested thatBrexit was delayed, it ought to be for longer than the two months posited by Number , eventhat meant fighting the next European elections.The ardent Corbyn-supporter was speaking after Labour MSPs discussed the latest developments on Brexit at their weekly meeting at Holyrood today.He said thatLabour could not amend Theresa Mayrsquos deal as it wished, the party would back a second vote offering a choice between Remain and a ldquocredible Leave option.He said Leave options might security cooperation, and guarantees on workers rights, consumer protection and the environment.Asked whether his preference was for that deal or a referendum, he said: ldquoFor that deal.Scots voted - against Brexit in , and polls show similar numbers of Scots continue to oppose it.Asked why he was setting himself against the majority of Scottish voters, Mr Leonard said: ldquoWell, because the referendum on the EU in the end was a UK-wide franchise, and that was the outcome of the people who took part.:Most Scottish Labour MPs now back new Brexit voteMr Leonard, who became leader in to find a deal thatrsquos acceptable.ldquoI think that there is growing evidence from the European Commission that they are prepared to lend credibility to the Labour option which is going to be put proper consideration to that and I sincerely hope that the UK parliament would vote for that.Askedhe was therefore happy with an extension that took the UK into the next European Parliament session, he said: ldquoI actually think that this decision is more important than the electoral cycle of the European parliament.:Richard Leonard on Brexit: Now is the time to act and act radicallyHe said Labourrsquos Scottish Executive Committee had already discussed what it would do in the event of it having to contest the European poll in May, but refused to reveal them.Labour won two of the six MEP positions in Scotland at the last election in .However one of those MEPs, Catherine Stihler, has already stood down to take up another job, meaning the party might need to find another candidate rapidly.Asked about Nicola Sturgeon ldquomaking hay with Mr Leonard backing Brexit, Scottish Labour Brexit spokesman Neil Findlay said: ldquoNicola Sturgeon has had about seven dferent positions on Brexit. She has regularly called for there to be a customs union.ldquoI think she would support Labourrsquos position in terms of the rights of people, whether they be workers or protecting the environment or all the rest of it. I donrsquot think therersquos a great deal in the Labour proposals that...they would object to.:Blow for Richard Leonard as leak reveals , Labour membership slump across ScotlandIan Murray, the Labour MP for Edinburgh South, who has campaigned for a Peoples Vote, said: "These comments will disappoint many Scottish Labour members. There is no good Brexit, no jobs-first Brexit, and no better Labour Brexit. Nothing is as good as what we currently enjoy as a member of the EU."Jeremy Corbyn, Keir Starmer and Emily Thornberry have been clear. We should have a public vote with the Prime Ministers deal versus remain on the ballot paper, and we must back remain for the sake of jobs and livelihoods in Scotland and across the UK."SNP MSP George Adam said:ldquoRichard Leonard has today confirmed that Scottish Labour is pro-Brexit ndash something that will utterly dismay many of its own supporters.ldquoThe clock is ticking on Brexit and we desperately need parties to work together against Theresa Mayrsquos bad deal and against no-deal. ldquoBut almost as soon as Labour say they could support a second referendum, Richard Leonard says it would be better for Brexit to go ahead.ldquoThat puts Labour completely at odds with the Scottish people ndash and it makes their apparent embrace of a second referendum look cynical in the extreme.ldquoItrsquos time for all parties to throw their weight behind a public vote, with Remain on the ballot, and put an end to this Brexit mess.Tory MSP Adam Tomkins added:ldquoEven Richard Leonard is now admitting the utter shambles his party have gotten themselves into over Brexit.ldquoAllowing a second EU referendum sets a dangerous precedent, and as he admits himself, it could lead to a second independence referendum.ldquoIt just goes to show once again how weak Labour are on the Union ndash they are willing to sell it out for political expediency.ldquoOnly the Scottish Conservatives are willing and able to stand up to the SNP and their plans to rip Scotland out of the UK.Scottish LibDem leader Willie Rennie condemned Mr Leonards red Brexit.He said: "Brexit would be bad for the economy and public services whether you paint it blue or red."Like Jeremy Corbyn, Richard Leonard has been reluctantly manoeuvred towards a Peoplersquos Vote but itrsquos disappointing that they are still not ruling out a Labour led Brexit.ldquoAnyone in the Labour party disappointed by the cynical triangulation of the Labour leadership should know that Scottish Liberal Democrats have been unwavering in support of a Peoplersquos Vote and the chance to remain in the EU.

title: theresa-may-performs-screeching-u-turn-to-give-mps-chance-to-put-back-brexit-day-until-summer
story: The humiliating move followed the threat by some ministers to resignshe did not cave in to parliamentary pressure.In another twist to the Westminster drama, the Prime Minister made her move less than  hours after she insisted a delay would be pointless and that she was determined Britain would leave the EU on the scheduled date with a deal.Read more:Richard Leonard defies majority of Scots to back Brexit over second referendumBut she dramatically changed tack after it emerged that some  rebels had secretly met the night before in the Commons to discuss how to stop a no-deal outcome with as many as  said to be prepared to resign.Three ministers, Claire Perry, Richard Harrington and Margot James went public to ldquoimplore Mrs May to extend the Article  processher deal were rejected by Parliament by March . It followed a similar request at the weekend by three Cabinet ministers Amber Rudd, Greg Clark and David Gauke.Earlier this month, The Herald revealed how a Cabinet minister had predicted that the PM would come up with a last-minute ldquoform of words to allay his and other ministersrsquo fears to make clear Britain would not leave on March  without a deal.In a Commons statement ahead of another next steps vote tomorrow, the PM said she appreciated how MPs from all parties were ldquogenuinely worried that time was running out and that,the Government failed to come back with a further meaningful vote or lost that vote, Parliament would not have time to make its voice heard on the next steps.So she pledged to give three further commitments:Mrs May made clear: ldquoSo the United Kingdom will only leave without a deal on March ,there is explicit consent in this House for that outcome.But she repeatedly refused to say how she would vote on the second key vote ndash on whether the UK should leave without a deal.Read more:Jeremy Corbyn faces backlash over second referendum planLabourrsquos Owen Smith, who accused the PM of carrying out a "screeching U-turn," asked: "Could she be clear - because she hasnt been thus far -we have that vote on March  or , will her Government be voting in favour of no-deal or against it "The PM replied: "Im getting conflicting views from across the chamber on one hand, Im told nothing has changed, on the other hand, Im told weve done a U-turn."She failed to answer a similar question about whipping arrangements by Labourrsquos Jess Phillips and when another Labour backbencher Stella Creasy pressed Mrs May how she would vote on the no-deal option, the PM insisted she would vote for a deal.Later, her spokesman, when asked about whipping arrangements, insisted such questions were ldquofor another day, and that what the Government was focused on was a successful vote on the PMrsquos Plan B by March .Quizzed on why Mrs May had U-turned, her spokesman said: ldquoClearly, the way that we leave with a deal is to get that accepted by Parliament and there are strong views on all aspects on Brexit and how that happens and this is an acknowledgement of that.Askedthe threat of ministerial resignations had played a part, he stressed: ldquoWe are not saying that, pointing out how the Cooper amendment,passed, would have serious consequences for the way the country was governed and that balance of power in Parliament.No  made clear that the weekly Cabinet had endorsed Mrs Mayrsquos change of tack on an extension, saying: ldquoThere was broad agreement that this was the way to proceed.It stressed the issue of resignations was not raised. But Liz Truss, the Treasury Chief Secretary, branded Ms Rudd, Mr Clark and Mr Gauke ldquokamikaze Cabinet Ministers over the way they had pressured the PM over a delay to Brexitthere was no majority for her deal.Senior ministers Liam Fox, Gavin Williamson and Andrea Leadsom were said to have made clear their concerns about the PMrsquos three-point plan.In her statement, Mrs May insisted she did not want to extend Article  and her ldquoabsolute focus was on getting a deal by March .However, she pointed out how an extension beyond the end of June would mean the UK taking part in the European Parliament elections.ldquoWhat kind of message would that send to the more than  million people who voted to leave the EU nearly three years ago now The PM went on: ldquoAnd the House should be clear that a short extension - not beyond the end of June - would almost certainly have to be a one-off. If we had not taken part in the European Parliament elections, it would be extremely dficult to extend again, so it would create a much sharper clf-edge in a few monthsrsquo time.Jeremy Corbyn said he had "lost count" of Mrs Mayrsquos explanations for her "grotesquely reckless" delays.The Labour leader accused the PM of promising to achieve "something she knows is not achievable" and her "obstinacy" was the block to a resolution."Will she be straight with people  The Withdrawal Agreement is not being reopened, there is no attempt to get a unilateral exit on the backstop or a time limit. She has so far promised a vote on her deal in December, January, February and now March, and only managed to put a vote once - in January when it was comprehensively defeated.Mr Corbyn added: ldquoThe Prime Minister continues to say it is her deal or no-deal but this House has decisively rejected her deal and has clearly rejected no-deal. It is the Prime Ministers obstinacy that is blocking a resolution."Mrs May hit back, attacking Mr Corbynrsquos decision to swing Labour behind a second EU referendum."He has gone back on his promise to respect the referendum result and now wants to hold a isive second referendum that would take our country right back to square one."Anyone who voted Labour at the last election because they thought he would deliver Brexit will rightly be appalled," she declared.But she came under fresh fire from Ian Blackford, who said the PM "could not be trusted" not to "dodge" another meaningful vote.The SNP leader claimed it was the ldquoheight of irresponsibility for any government to threaten its citizens with the consequences of a no-deal Brexit."Rule out no-deal, extend Article  but do it today this should not be left until the middle of March," declared the Highland MP.Mrs May explained the deal would not be brought back to MPs until March  because the Government was still negotiating."We are in talks with the EU and were talking about the issues this House required. If he wants to end the uncertainty and deal with the issues he raised...then he should vote for a deal. Simples," she added.Ken Clarke, the former Chancellor, asked about theof any delay, saying: "She seems to be giving us a date for a new clf-edge at the end of June but isnt the danger that we will merely continue the present pantomime performance through the next three months and the public will be dismayed as we approach that date and find there is similar chaos about where were going."The PM accepted that an extension would mean having to go through a second stage of negotiations but she stressed she would want any delay to Brexit to be ldquoas short as possible".Later, her spokesman was asked what would happenMPs voted against all three options - the PMrsquos new plan, a no-deal Brexit and extending Article  - he replied: ldquoThat would be quite contradictory and an unexpected thing to happen.

title: teacher-pay-talks-continue-as-strikes-loom
story: The move comes after members of the Educational Institute of Scotlandvoted last week to reject the bid.The EIS will now move to hold a ballot on industrial action, but they have also agreed to continue talks with councils and the Government.Larry Flanagan, general secretary of the EIS, said: ldquoAt the meeting we presented the recent EIS ballot result, and indicated our intended move to a statutory ballot for strike action.Read more: Teachers to open strike ballotldquoThis provides clear evidence of the need for the other parties to improve the offer in order to gain acceptance from teachers.ldquoWe also reiterated that the EIS is continuing to seek a negotiated settlement, that we were willing to meet at any time, and that strike action would be a last resort.The latest offer from the Scottish Government and council umbrella body Cosla was three per cent from April last year with a further three per cent from January, an additional three per cent in April and another three per cent in April next year.In recognition of concern over problems in the recruitment and retention of teachers Cosla has also agreed to back a restructuring of wider pay scales and took at pay for promoted teachers.Read more: How likely are school strikes over payHowever, teaching unions had campaigned for an immediate  per cent rise for all staff arguing salaries have fallen behind over the past decade. More than  per cent of EIS members voted to back the deal, but  per cent rejected it.Gail Macgregor, resources spokeswoman for council umbrella body Cosla, said: ldquoWe are committed to continuing to try and achieve a negotiated settlement.ldquoThis is very much Coslarsquos position and the reason that we are prepared to meet again next week.

title: wait-for-sentencing-guidelines-branded-unacceptable
story: The Lord Justice Clerk Lady Dorrian, the chair of the Scottish Sentencing Council, said rushed advice could backfire on iniduals and the justice system as as whole.Lady Dorrian spoke out ahead of a Labour-led debate at Holyrood today condemning the councilrsquos failure to produce guidance on sexual assaults, despite a rise in cases.Although the Council has started work on the subject, its guidance will not be ready until after .Labour last week urged the body to prioritise sexual assault guidance after the Christopher Daniel case.The -year-old dental student from Glasgow was granted an absolute discharge last month despite being found guilty of repeatedly sexually assaulting a six-year-old girl.Sherf Gerald Sinclair ruled that Daniel had been motivated by ldquoentirely inappropriate curiosity rather than sexual gratication, and the girl ldquoappeared to have suffered no injury or long lasting effects.Labour will urge MSPs to condemn the ldquounacceptable timescale for the new guidelines.MSP Daniel Johnson said: ldquoWe need to reform and improve sentencing policy in Scotland, ensuring there is transparency in the system so that victims and their families can have confidence in it.ldquoThat starts with Holyrood accepting there is an issue.The Scottish Government will try to amend Labourrsquos motion to commend the councilrsquos ldquoinitial focus of its work on sexual offences and urge ldquoconsensus on the subject.In a y response to vote, Lady Dorrian stressed the Councilrsquos work was based on extensive evidence taking and careful consideration of all aspects of the issues involved.She said: ldquoWhile we do not anticipate guidelines on sexual offences being finalised during the current business plan period [-], this is not a delay but simply reflects the Councilrsquos current work programme and the likely work involved in addressing this subject.ldquoWe have already held initial discussions with the judiciary and with a range of organisations with interest and experience in the sentencing of sexual offences, including victim support organisations, and we have begun research into public views in this area.ldquoIt is likely that the Council will develop multiple guidelines on sexual offending, and we hope to announce the areas of initial focus soon. It is vital that any guidelines we produce are well-researched and fit for purpose.Reflecting on another aspect of the Daniel case, Tory MSP Liam Kerr added: ldquoIt is astonishing that the sexual assault of a six year old has led to no criminal conviction and no punishment. It should be easier for lenient sentences to be appealed in the public interest ndash and the Scottish Law Commission should consider reviewing this area.

title: tory-brexiters-cry-betrayal-after-theresa-may-u-turns-on-delaying-eu-withdrawal

title: analysis-corbyn-and-may-face-up-to-political-reality-and-shift-brexit-positions
story: First up this week was Jeremy Corbyn, who on Monday performed a humiliating U-turn on a Peoplersquos Vote.It is not dficult to see why the Labour leader decided, against his own instincts, to back the option.A poll, which asked people their voting preferences were Westminsterrsquos newly-formed centrist group a fully-fledged party, produced some alarming numbers for the Labour leader.It put the Tories on  per cent, a not insubstantial  points ahead of Labour on  with TIG on  and the Liberal Democrats on six.ButTIG and the Lib Dems were to merge at some point ndash as some hope - then on these numbers, the combined force would put Labour into third place. Food for thought.Next up was Theresa May, who, less than  hours after saying what a pointless exercise delaying Brexit would be, announced she was paving the way for a delay to Brexit.Cries of betrayal and plots continued to ping around the oak-led walls of Westminster from both sides of the political ide.Today, MPs will, yes, have yet another vote.Mrs Mayrsquos ploy of offering an extension vote on March  has at least done one thing seemingly scuppered Yvette Cooperrsquos bid to empower Parliament to ensure a no-deal is taken off the table.Her co-sponsor of her amendment, the former Tory Cabinet minister Oliver Letwin, took to Twitter to say he was removing his support for it, declaring the PMrsquos move meant ldquono need now for Cooper-Letwin Bill.So the only drama on Wednesday night could come from a Labour-backed Tory amendment on citizensrsquo rights.Conservative backbencher Alberto Costa has predicted an "enormous defeat" for Mrs May unless she gives in to demands to seek a separate treaty on citizens rights after Brexit. However, the Scotrsquos defiance could cost him his job as Scottish Secretary David Mundellrsquos parliamentary private secretary.The focus will quickly turn to mid-March when MPs are set to have not one, not two but three votes respectively on the PMrsquos new-look plan, a no-deal and extending Article .While Mrs May insists progress is being made, the UK-EU talks seem as far away from a resolution as ever the assumption at Westminster is whatever the PM s with on March  will not be enough.She was coy yesterday about how she and her Government would vote on the second vote on no-deal. Rightly so, as by then it could be Brexiteer ministers and not Remainers threatening resignation.Then will come the crunch third vote on extension. In such circumstances this will pass. But the key question will be: how long will be the delay Mrs May wants it ldquoas short as possible but MPs could successfully amend the motion to extend Article  for months.Whatever timeline MPs agree, there is then the little matter of getting the EU to endorse it.By then, Brussels will have the UK over a barrel becauseit were not to agree, then there would be nothing to stop the country crashing out of the bloc without a deal two weeks later.Then, of course, the Brexit monster might have yet another twist to torment us with.Asked what would happenMPs voted against all three options, the PMrsquo spokesman paused and said: ldquoThat would be quite contradictory and an unexpected thing to happen.But as we know in this never-ending psychodrama, anything can happen.

title: outlander-boost-for-scotlands-heritage-sites
story: The historic sites manned by the staff of Historic Environment Scotlandhave reported an increase in footfall to ,, people in , a five per cent increase on .The Amazon Prime series Outlander, the time-travel historical drama based on the best selling books by Diana Gabaldon, is shot at ious locations, including Doune Castle, Craigmillar Castle, Blackness Castle, Linlithgow Castle and Aberdour Castle: all have experienced record years.The most-visited staffed site was Edinburgh Castle with ,, visitors, a figure which is a rise of % on the previous year.Stirling Castle was the second-top visited site with , visitors, up %, followed by , visitors to Urquhart Castle.This is the first time Urquhart Castle has welcomed over , visitors in a single year, and represents a rise of % in visitors.Blackness Castle reaching , visitors for the first time ndash an increase of % from the previous year.The th century fortress is the setting for the Fort William headquarters of ldquoBlack Jack Randall in the series, while Doune Castle is the location for the fictional Castle Leoch in the series.Outlander premiered in , and much of its filming is done in Scotland, on location at historic sites, including the Old Town of Edinburgh, as well as purpose-built studios in Cumbernauld.The show, which stars Sam Heughan as Jamie Fraser and Caitriona Balfe as Claire Randall in its lead roles, has been a success for its producers Starz: they have agreed to make fth and sixth seasons.HES also had a record number of memberships in  which peaked at over , ndash up from % in .In total,  of the top  visited sites run by the HES registered record attendances.Sites staffed by the HES, they reported, generated poundm of local tourism expenditure in  ndash up poundm from  - and supported more than , full time equivalent jobs.Stephen Duncan, its director for commercial and tourism, said: ldquo was another fantastic year for Scotlandrsquos heritage sites, with visitor numbers continuing to grow.ldquoAs well as the lsquoOutlander effectrsquo bringing international visitors to Scotland to explore its rich history, we have also seen an increase in the number of Scots visiting heritage sites as evidenced in our highest ever membership figure.ldquoWith Scotland being used as a filming location for productions such as Outlaw King and Mary Queen of Scots, we hope visitors will continue to be inspired to explore the history of the sites they see on the big screen.Some of the HES sites were boosted by having the Lego exhibition, Brick Wonders, at their location: notably Glasgow Cathedral, Aberdour Castle, Arbroath Abbey and Stirling Castle.HES added that bad weather, which was dubbed the Beast from the East, affected sites at the beginning of , but overall there had been a steady increase in footfall.HES looks after  heritage sites in total, including  staffed Historic Scotland sites.Mr Duncan added: ldquoThese incredible figures show the importance that the historic environment has on local communities with the vast majority of economic growth generated by the increase in high-spending international visitors.ldquoFrom abbeys in the Borders to Norse settlements in Shetland, the appeal of Scotlandrsquos cultural heritage reaches far and wide and is there to be enjoyed by all.HES has made some investments in some of the sites.This includes a pound, investment project at Edinburgh Castle.He added: ldquoAnother commitment was to reach new audiences, particularly with the Year of Young People.ldquoWe launched Knight at the Castle, the first after-hours event at Edinburgh Castle targeting young people, and our touring LEGO exhibitions were a huge success across our regional sites with Aberdour Castle seeing a % increase in visitors from the previous year.Fiona Hyslop, the culture secretary, said: ldquoI would like to thank all those who contribute to caring for our precious and unique heritage.ldquoScotlandrsquos historic environment is a catalyst for economic growth ndash driving tourism, regeneration and sustainable development, and fuelling improvements.ldquoI am delighted Historic Environment Scotland has seen an increase in title: energy-giant-plans-hefty-investment-in-windfarms-and-car-chargers-in-scotland
story: The Glasgow-based energy giant said it wants to play a key role in the push to reduce carbon emissions by helping electry the economy where it matters most: in transport and heating.Read more: Energy price cap branded con as Scots energy bills set to riseThe company and big six rivals came under fire last week for announcing price rises after Ofgem said it would lt the cap on charges.ScottishPowers programme will involve the Spanish-owned group investing in generating more renewable energy and in the facilities required to help ensure consumers make the most of its potential.The company said it will start installing fast chargers across the UK at strategic commercial locations from winter  in a move it reckons will unlock the market for electric vehicle ownership.It is understood this will involve installing kit in places that would allow drivers to make charging their cars part of their routine, such as out of town shopping centres.ldquoOnshore wind remains the lowest cost technology for new electricity generation in the UK and ScottishPower sees substantial opportunities for the continued development of onshore wind projects across Scotland and other areas of the UK, said the company.ScottishPower also announced plans to develop a pioneering battery storage project at the giant Whitelee onshore windfarm on Eaglesham Moor south of Glasgow, which is the biggest in the UK. This could be used to ensure power is available to meet iations in demand.The company said the large-scale battery project will be the first of a series of storage schemes in the UK, which will be mainly located at windfarms and at strategic points on the network.Read more: ScottishPower boss hails pivotal year as profits rise %It reckons the combination of renewable energy and flexible storage provides the most cost-effective low carbon solution for consumers.ScottishPowerrsquos offshore wind development effort is focused on the waters off eastern England.The  investment plan is expected to result in the company creating around  jobs, a signicant number of which will be in Scotland.Chief executive Keith Anderson said the plan was a historic milestone for ScottishPower and provided a vote of confidence in the UKrsquos commitment to decarbonising the economy. ScottishPower invested pound.bn in clean energy in .ldquoConsumers want and need access to reliable, clean and affordable energy, he said. ldquoThat is what ScottishPower is focused on delivering and as long as Government climate change commitments stay firm, with sensible policies to support them, this investment will continue.The company expects to spend poundbn in the UK between  and .It unveiled the investment plan days after posting a  per cent increase in profits, to pound.bn, for . Mr Anderson said the year had been pivotal for the company.The firm completed the ldquolandmark journey from coal and gas to % green power by selling its conventional generation business to Drax for poundm in October.Read more: Power gianteyes growth in Scotland after poundm move into countryThe unit includes a giant reservoir-based power generator in Argyll, the Lanark and Galloway hydro-electric facilities on rivers in South West Scotland and a biomass fuel plant near Glasgow, along with four gas-fired power stations in England.Drax said yesterday the assets were highly complementary to its strategy and would form a very important part of its portfolio. The company expects the assets to provide high quality earnings.It aims to support the move to renewables by investing in generating and storage facilities that will complement wind and solar output.Drax has adapted the giant coal-fired power station in Yorkshire from which it takes its name to run partially on wood pellets.The head of its power generation business, Andy Koss, said the company was very pleased with the assets acquired from ScottishPower. It could invest signicant amounts in developing them with the right official support.Mr Koss highlighted the role the Cruachan pumped storage facility in Argyll played in ensuring supplies are made available to the national grid when needed.Read more: How Cruachan power plant worksCruachan generates power based on the movement of water between a reservoir in the hills and Loch Awe, which lies around  metres below.Mr Koss said Drax is considering development options for Cruachan that could include hollowing out the mountain to build a new turbine hall or constructing a new dam.Drax grew underlying profits by % to poundm last year.Last week ScottishPower said it was raising its prices for customers on standard iable tarfsby  per cent - pound a year . The increase will mean its standard plan for duel fuel customers will cost on average pound,.Other members of the big sixhave increased prices for customers on SVTs recently sinceOfgem decided to raise the typical limit for UK default and standard iable gas and electricity tarfs by pound to pound, a year from April .ScottishPowerrsquos parent group, Iberdrola, said yesterday it would invest eurobnby  to speed growth. It reckons the plan will provide a major boost to the irreversible transition to a low carbon-energy model.

title: scottish-wildcat-population-no-longer-viable
story: A report into efforts to preserve the few remaining Highland Tigers found that the number left in the wild is now too low to represent a "viable" population. Fewer than  are thought to remain in the wild.Efforts should now be focussed on revitalising the species through captive breeding programmes or re-introducing wildcats from northern Europe.Once wide-ranging across much of rural Scotland, the last wildcats are now confined to isolated pockets of the Highlands.Wildcat numbers have fallen to unsustainable levelsHybridisation ndash the breeding of domestic pet and feral cats with wildcats ndash and a loss of habitat have been blamed for the species decline.Other factors were said to be road traffic accidents and dwindling food sources, and efforts to keep down other predators which inadvertently targeted wildcats.Ongoing efforts to preserve populations in the wild have also failed, although population estimates may have been too high to begin with.: Saving the wildcathellip now only a whisker away from extinctionThe study was carried out by International Union for Conservation of Nature rsquos Cat Specialist Group at the behest of Scottish Wildcat Action , starting last year and examining all the current data on wildcats and the ious efforts to preserve the species.It said: "All the robust information available indicates that the wildcat in Scotland is at the verge of extinction."Based on the available information, we consider the wildcat population in Scotland to be no longer viable."The number of wildcats is too small, the hybridisation too far advanced and the population too fragmented."The report added: "We therefore conclude that it is too late to conserve the wildcat in Scotland as a stand-alone population."Conservationists say they will battle on to preserve wildcatsThe elusive wildcat has long been one of the UKrsquos most endangered mammals. Previous studies have cited hybridisation as the major threat to their survival in the wild, but this is the first time researchers have concluded it has contributed to the species dying out on a genetic level.:Claws are out in battle to save Scottish wildcat from extinction#Scottish Wildcat Action Steering Group Chair, Dr Andrew Kitchener, Principal Curator of Vertebrates at National Museums Scotland said: ldquoWe now have the strongest and most reliable evidence to date that wildcats are in a more endangered state than previously understood."While we believe there are wildcats remaining in the wild in Scotland, there are no longer enough to ensure their continued survival as viable populations."However, options are now being examined to revitalise populations in the wold, possibly by introducing wildcats captured in northern Europe, or through a breeding programme with captive-bred wildcats.Dr Kitchener said: "We can now plan the essential next steps to give the wildcat a sustainable future.RZSS CEO Barbara Smith, SNHs Head of People  Nature, Eileen Stuart, and Scotlands Environment Secretary, Roseanna Cunningham. Pic: SNH Lorne Gill.Roseanna Cunningham, the Scottish Governments Cabinet Secretary for the Environment, Climate Change and Land Reform, also pledged not to give up the fight.She said: ldquoThis report presents us with further evidence of the serious challenges that wildcat conservation faces in Scotland."The wildcat is an iconic Scottish species and, as such, I will consider every possible action the Scottish Government can take to save it, including an increased focus on captive breeding and reinforcement of the Scottish population with wildcats from where."We have in place a partnership of scientists and specialists with the knowledge and expertise to give us the best chance of restoring the Highland Tiger as a distinctive and charismatic species in the Scottish countryside, and I look forward to working with them to make this a reality.A wildcat, most likely a hybrid, spotted on Mull. Pic: Peter Harris PACat Conservation Project Officer at the Royal Zoological Society of Scotland, David Barclay, added: ldquoWe know the road ahead for wildcat recovery will be challenging, but our strong partnerships with SWA and international conservation specialists give us an incredible opportunity for success.ldquoOur plans for a National Wildle Reintroduction Centre at Highland Wildle Park will provide the perfect environment for breeding genetically tested wildcats with the aim of releasing them back to the wild to re-establish viable populations in key locations.:Wildcat kittens could provide leline for species#ldquoCombined with the continued development of the conservation breeding programme, this will ensure we have a long-term solution for the recovery and conservation of this iconic species.ldquoTogether we can restore Scotlands wildcats to their rightful place as an integral link in a thriving ecosystem.

title: five-stars-the-dark-carnival-tramway-glasgow
story: The Dark CarnivalTramway, GlasgowNeil CooperFive starsSomething is stirring beneath the cold, dark earth in Vanishing Pointrsquos rollicking graveyard opera, brought to le by director Matthew Lenton in an epic co-production with the Citizens Theatre in association with Dundee Rep. There are bodies asleep in coffins piled on top of each other as Elicia Dalyrsquos narrator wanders into the light, before Bf Smith and his pasty-faced street corner cabaret band strike up the first of a string of chansons that soundtrack a night of the undead. Above them, mourners pay assorted respects to their loved ones. Higher still, drunken angels keep their own council, enjoying the fruits of their out of touch immortality.What emerges out of designer Kenneth MacLeodrsquos magnicent funereal set is a series of noisy visual tableaux to accompany the live music inbetween rhymed exchanges between the eccentric members of an accidentally thrown together underground community. With the sixteen-strong ensemble swathed in celestial light and shade conjured up by Simon Wilkinson, this makes for a slow-burning meditation on le, death and the messy bits inbetween, where any chance of resting in peace is unlikely.As with much of Vanishing Pointrsquos previous work, there is plenty to reflect on here about loss and grieving. This lends a poignancy to things, especially as related in Dalyrsquos magnicently quasi-Dickensian delivery. This time out, however, there is a kind of bittersweet acceptance and a playful levity pulsing things. So while there are ghosts haunting them all, from Malcolm Cummingrsquos Young John and Peter Kellyrsquos Old Peter who mourns him, the peace they crave is enlivened by a song and dance routine to brighten up their sorry start of affairs.It takes the young, embodied here in the spirit of Olivia Barrowcloughrsquos Little Annie, to fight the collective inertia which binds them. From here, they rise up against those on high and storm Heavenrsquos gates, as each and everyone sings out for the great refusal, and for the joy of le itself.

title: mccrone-reacts-as-famous-scottish-independence-oil-report-published-in-newspaper
story: Professor Gavin McCrone said the situation had ldquocompletely changed, while plummeting oil prices in the second half of the s meant the massivesurplus would not have lasted.His comments came as the pro-independence National newspaper published the McCrone report, which was written and researched in  as a briefing to ministers before Labour took power, in its entirety.Prof McCrone, who was then a senior civil servant, told The Herald: ldquoWe had a situation in the s when there were enormous oil discoveries going on all the time, and the revenues were going to be very large.ldquoBut today, we are in a situation where the oil is declining in importance and the revenues have come a way down. The price, well ndash theyrsquove gone up slightly a bit, I suppose, but they will never be what they were.He said his analysis of Scotlandrsquos ldquoembarrassing surplus would not have lasted, because ldquothe oil price came rattling down in the second half of the s.He added: ldquoIt might have been the case at the time. I think these things were probably put in my report to make ministers wake up to the importance of the thing.The -year-old said oil was ldquostill important, but itrsquos nothing like as important as it was back then.Prof McCronersquos  report said the discovery of North Sea oil had ldquocompletely overturned the traditional economic arguments used against Scottish nationalism.It added: ldquoAn independent Scotland could now expect to have massive surpluses both on its budget and on its balance of payments and with the proper husbanding of resources this situation could last for a very long time into the future.It said that ldquofor the first time since the Act of Union was passed, it can now be credibly argued that Scotlandrsquos economic advantage lies in its repeal.Elsewhere, it stated: ldquo[An independent Scotland] would tend to be in chronic surplus to a quite embarrassing degree and its currency would become the hardest in Europe, with the exception perhaps of the Norwegian kroner.The report was classied as ldquosecret and given a restricted circulation because of the "extreme sensitivity of the subject", and only came to light in  following a Freedom of Information request by an SNP researcher.Prof McCrone told The Herald he was surprised by the totemic place it now holds in Scottish debate as he never thought it would see the light of day, but said henever felt it was hushed up.He said: ldquoMy thing was never intended to be published. It was a confidential report for ministers ndash these things always are, protected by ious rules.He added: ldquoI didnrsquot expect it to be published. I didnrsquot write it to be published. And I didnrsquot really expect it to be leaked either ndash maybe I should have thought it might have been, but it wasnrsquot.He said he was abroad when the report was initially released in full  years ago, and was ldquoquite amused to come back and find it being discussed.But Prof McCrone said he still believed in setting up an oil fund, even"you wouldnt have nearly so much to put into it now".He said such a move in the s would have ldquomade the situation much easier when we got to the financial crashes.He said: ldquoThe danger when you have a very wealthy resource like that is it crowds out the rest of the economy, of course, and that would have been something that would have had to be facedScotland had been independent.ldquoNorway took measures to deal with that, more or less successfully, but Irsquom not sure whether Scotland would have done. One just doesnrsquot know. The UK didnrsquot really.He continued: ldquoI thought Norway were very sensible with what they did. But then they are a dferent country from the UK.ldquoNorway is a country with a population about the size of Scotland, and the UK had a population of between  and  million I think, at that time, and had a lot of problems.ldquoThe s were a very, very dficult period for any government, whichever government was in office, and so itrsquos perhaps understandable that they just wanted to take advantage of the oil revenues and that was that.

title: trade-union-donations-to-labour-reach-record-low
story: The total of pound. million received from the partys traditional backers was the lowest in any year since Electoral Commission records started in .The commission revealed donation totals for the final three months of last year, which showed Theresa Mays Conservatives taking in almost pound. million - more than four times the amount to Jeremy Corbyns party.Labours pound. million in donations over the fourth quarter was outstripped by the pound,, it received from public funds, much of it made up of the "Short money" provided to help opposition parties fund their work in the Commons.Read more:Jeremy Corbyn warned Peoples Vote sht will have catastrophic electoral consequences for LabourThe pound. million received by Labour from unions compares with almost pound million during the election year of , around pound million in  and pound million in .Labour received more than pound million a year from unions in non-election years under Ed Milibands leadership.The pound,, received by Tories made up almost three-quarters of the total pound,, donated to political parties in Britain in the last three months of the year.In the same period, Sir Vince Cables Liberal Democrats received pound, in donations and pound, from public funds.The figures mean that over the course of  Conservatives took in donations totalling more than pound million, compared with less than pound million for Labour and pound. million for the Lib Dems.Read more:Ian Austin becomes latest MP to quit Labour partyThe biggest gt to the Tories in the fourth quarter was pound. million from musical theatre producer John Gore, a regular donor to the party. Construction vehicle manufacturer JCB gave pound, and former Tory treasurer Michael Spencers IPGL gave pound,.Labours biggest donor was the Unite union, with a pound, gt.The Scottish National Partys pound, in gts from just three donors over the three-month period was dwarfed by the pound, received from public funds.Greens took in pound, in donations and pound, from public funds, and Plaid Cymru had just one donation of pound, and took pound, from public funds.The UK Independence Party received just pound, in donations.

title: sajid-javid-stuns-mps-by-backing-bid-to-secure-eu-citizens-rights-after-no-deal-after-theresa-may-dismissed-it
story: :Theresa May attacks SNP over workplace parking taxThe Prime Minister was expected to go down to defeat in the Commons on Wednesday on the amendment from Tory MP Alberto Costa, after Jeremy Corbyn announced that Labour would support it.Mr Costas office was unable to confirm or deny reports that the South Leicestershire MP was standing down as a parliamentary aide to Scotland Secretary David Mundell in order to push his plan.Mr Javid appeared to be caught by surprise while answering questions before a parliamentary committee to hear that his support for the move was not shared by Mrs May.He told the Home Affairs Select Committee there was "nothing" wrong Mr Costas proposals.Asked by SNP committee member Stuart McDonald whether the Government was now supporting them, he replied: "Yes, what do you mean now  When was the Government not supporting it  When did you hear that "When Mr McDonald said "Yesterday", Mr Javid asked: "From who "The SNP MP replied: "The Prime Minister."A visibly nonplussed Home Secretary replied: "Did you  Right... Oh... OK. Im perfectly happy with the amendment."What Mr Costa is doing, which I think is perfectly correct, is trying to find more ways for Parliament to give that reassurance."More than  Conservatives are among the  MPs who have signed the amendment, which calls for a separate agreement with the European Union to protect the rights of expats eventhere is a no-deal Brexit.Among those signing are former leader Iain Duncan Smith, European Research Group chair Jacob Rees-Mogg and leading pro-EU Tories like Dominic Grieve.:McCrone reacts as famous Scottish independence oil report published in newspaperAfter Labour announced it was supporting the amendment, Mr Costa said it would be a "farce"the Government did not back down.He told the Press Association on Tuesday: "If the Government werent to accept this tomorrow, they will be staring an enormous defeat in the face."And he acknowledged that his job as a parliamentary private secretarywas on the line as a result of his actions."I have considered my position and I have tabled the amendment," he said then. "It is entirely in the hands of Government to decide who is and is not a PPS. I will continue in my role until told otherwise."In the Commons on Tuesday, Mrs May acknowledged concerns about citizens rightsher deal did not go through.She said that the Government had guaranteed "the rights of the three million EU citizens living in the UK will be protected"."But a separate agreement for citizens rights is something the EU have been clear they do not have the legal authority for," she said."If it is not done in a Withdrawal Agreement, these issues become a matter for member states unless the EU were to agree a new mandate to take this forward."Foreign Secretary Jeremy Hunt was seeking assurances from counterparts in EU states on the issue, she said, adding: "I urge all EU countries to make this guarantee and end the uncertainty for these citizens."

title: highland-council-confident-that-overspent-budget-can-be-brought-back-on-track
story: Costs of looked after children and those with additional support needs were identied as some of the areas causing the overspend.Some children have had to be placed outwith the Highlands in expensive placements, and has offset the planned reduction in costs.The council put measures in place to address the crisis in November , when the overspend was projected.Read more:Councils have already spent entire winter roads budgetThey say vacancy controls,restricting non-essential expenditure, stopping non-essential travel and utilisingearmarked balances were executed.Agency and overtime spending was alsosignicantly restricted.A review of earmarked reserves is to take place to seeany funding previously set aside can be released for general use.Budget leader and chair of resources, Alister Mackinnon said: "I am confident that the correct measures are in place to bring the budget back into line."Some of the measures have been very dficult for some areas and I appreciate the efforts by many staff to improve our position.Read more:Scottish Labour warns of increased council charges over Budget deal"We simply cannot afford to weaken our reserves, so it is imperative that we continue with these restrictions for several more weeks and we need the commitment from everyone across the council to achieve a balanced position."Chief executive Donna Manson added: "The Corporate Plan will be coming to council next week and this will focus on scrutiny and driving performance."This and our Programme of Change will underpin the work of the council moving forward, ensuring that we use all our resources to the best effect to ensure we are an efficient, responsible and sustainable organisation."

story: A. title: firm s ice cream sales heat up
story: A scorching summer and increased exports has helped a north east firm achieve record revenues and profits from ice cream sales in .Mackie’s of Scotland has reported a record annual turnover of £. million and gross profit exceeding £. million for the financial year ending May .The company’s turnover was up % on the previous year thanks in part to boosted ice cream sales in supermarkets across the UK, increasing sales in the Far East, the addition of a range of chocolate bars and revenue from production of renewable energy on the Mackie’s farm at Westertown.Mackie’s enjoyed record-breaking sales in , with £. million turnover reported for ice cream and chocolate. Meanwhile its export sales to markets in the Far East soared by % to £. million - now contributing % to its total turnover.The company’s net assets were up by % and operating profit continued to rise, standing at £. million, with profits reinvested into the company, extending production with items like a new packaging machine in addition to investment in the Aberdeen ice cream parlour.Overall costs increased by % on the previous year, due in part to the continued high price of cream. Although its own -strong cow herd helps to buffer the impact of rising cream prices, during peak times in particular, the firm is required to buy extra cream at market prices.Mac Mackie, Managing Director at Mackie’s and one of three sibling owners, said: “ was certainly a signicant year for Mackie’s, with substantial growth in our export trade as well as developments closer to home.“Our current financial year has started well with the hot summer months with growth continuing into .” Coremetrics  Coremetrics  Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventID  "ELLO | Article Teaser"Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventCatID  "ELLO | Article Teaser"

title: james going for gold in gordon
story: The Liberal Democrats have selected their next candidate to be in the running for Gordon#s MP seat.The party has chosen James Oates, the nephew of long-serving former Gordon MP Malcolm Bruce.After graduating from Aberdeen University  years ago, he became a campaigner for human rights in Central and Eastern Europe.Multi-lingual, he later worked in the region for large investment firms such as JP Morgan, Robert Fleming and UBS, and for the past ten years he has been working with technology businesses in Tallinn, Estonia and building investment across the region.Commenting Mr Oates said: “I’m running to be Gordon’s MP because our country needs and wants to change. “It’s time to bring new energy, after the negativity of the past four years. It’s time for us to look the prosperity of the future and let go of the failed politics of the past.“It’s time for a new commitment to make sure that the opportunities in Gordon and in all of Scotland are recognised by the whole of the United Kingdom. Our contributions are not appreciated and our needs have been ignored for far too long.”He added: “I will not be one of those MPs that sits in London ignoring the people who put him there in the first place.“If I learned anything from Malcolm, it’s that cooperation, effective representation and respect for our communities are the most important traits I could have. My door will always be open.“I will bring Gordon and the needs of the Northeast to the Government, not the other way around.“It’s time our voices were heard again.” Coremetrics  Coremetrics  Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventID  "INVE | Article Teaser"Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventCatID  "INVE | Article Teaser"

title: oldmeldrum publican loses 2am licencing bid
story: An Oldmeldrum publican believes others in the trade are #wasting their time# applying for a am drinks licence after a failed bid by his own premises.Robin Philip, owner of Morris’s Hotel, was unsuccessful in his application for an extra hour on a Friday and Saturday for his public bar in a bid to boost dwindling trade.Dficult trading times in an economic climate hampered by increases in business rates and operating costs had prompted his application to extend weekend drinking times.However Aberdeenshire Central Licensing Board stuck to its policies which limits pubs and hotels to a am licence but which offers nightclubs am licences Sunday to Thursday and am on Fridays and Saturdays.The board had earlier heard objections to the later opening element of the application from Sgt Kim Wood on behalf of Police Scotland who said there was clear evidence that the longer and later on-sales licensed premises operate, the “higher the likelihood of incidents of crime, disorder and anti-social behaviour occurring”.But the Oldmeldrum publican stressed he had not experienced trouble in the  years he has run his business.He said the public bar only held  patrons who merely wanted to enjoy a slightly longer night out on a Saturday.Mr Philip said the crime figures presented by the police were for Ellon and Inverurie and had no bearing on Oldmeldrum.A motion by Cllr Marion Ewenson to approve elements of the application, including an outdoor drinking area, with the exception of the am Friday and Saturday extension, was unanimously approved.data-src"https:images-e.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! title: partnership for dentist and foodbank
story: An Inverurie dentist has teamed up with a local foodbank in a bid to offer much-needed support.Inverurie Smile Care has become formal Community Partners of the Inverurie Foodbank Centre.The Inverurie Foodbank Centre is part of Aberdeenshire North Foodbank, which has other food distribution centres in Ellon, Peterhead and Huntly as well as a central warehouse just outside Inverurie.The Foodbank Centre has been running in the town since .In  the Inverurie Foodbank Distribution Centre fulfilled  food parcel vouchers, providing food for the equivalent of  adults and  children - an  percent increase from .Commenting Debbie Rennie, Foodbank manager, said: “It is clear through their support of us since  and through recent discussions with them that they understand the need for the work that we are doing in the community and it is fantastic that they are supporting us with regular donations.“As much as we are worried about growing numbers of people needing emergency food parcels, what is positive about all of our Foodbank Centres, including Inverurie, is that local communities are coming together to meet local need through donating food, like Inverurie Smile Care have committed to doing, donating services, and the work of the foodbanks are predominantly done by local volunteers, which is so valuable.”Mohammed Khan, group marketing manager at Inverurie Smile Care added: “Be it regular foodbank donations, or sponsoring the Inverurie Academy Football teams, Smile Care are proud to be involved with the town of Inverurie: such engagement being a major, contributing factor to our award as ‘Scotland’s Best NHS Dental Practice’ at the Dentistry Scotland Awards .”data-src"https:images-e.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! title: Caithness to get firts vegan BB
story: A BED and breakfast with a dference is to be launched in Caithness next month.Barbara and Peter Gray, who live in Berriedale, will be opening what is thought to be the first vegan BB in the far north and the venture is already attracting interest online from people throughout the UK.The couple moved to Caithness in September after purchasing a property in the village.They come from Derbyshire but spent some time in Lincolnshire before moving to Golspie and then to Caithness.They say they both like the Highlands and wanted to set up a vegan bed and breakfast here.Barbara explained: ldquoWe saw the property at The Braes in Berriedale was up for sale last summer, put in an offer and it was accepted.ldquoAt present, we have a king size double en suite room but would hope to expand and have two to three rooms later.ldquoAs far as I know we are the only vegan BB in Caithness. I think the nearest one to us may be in Aviemore.ldquoFor a long time we have wanted to provide luxury accommodation and cooking for vegans but we will also show people how to cook vegan meals and may do workshops on an ad hoc basis as well as hosting special s for events such as Valentines Day and Burns Nights.ldquoWe will be open for business in March but are already getting interest online from people in the UK and hope eventually to generate interest in Europe and the USA.Asked what would happensomeone who is not a vegan wanted to stay at the BB, she replied: ldquoThey would have to take vegan food as we do not have animal products on the premises.ldquoWe live a vegan lestyle and would prefer vegans to stay here but they donrsquot have to be vegans.Her husband Peter helps run the business but is also a writer.He has been writing for many years but in  started work on a series of crime fiction books whose main character is Detective Inspector James Avalon. The police officer is based in Inverness but travels throughout the Highlands.Wednesday  Feb  : PM

title: Delay to Wick 20 mph speed limit plans
story: THE brakes have been put on plans to introduce a  mph speed limit on the majority of roads in Wick.The proposal was mooted by Highland Council as a way to improve road safety and encourage walking and cycling.However, Wick members of the Caithness committee this week described the scheme as "a blunt instrument" and said other measures to reduce speed would be more effective. They also felt the consultation period should be extended by three weeks to allow the public more time to respond to the plan.Speaking at the meeting in Wick Town Hall on Wednesday, Councillor Nicola Sinclair said she was "very much in favour" of improving road safety but was concerned about the scale of the  mph limit and claimed there should be a longer period of consultation."The consultation took place over the Christmas period and I dont think people got enough opportunity to get their views heard," she said.Full report in Fridayrsquos John OrsquoGroat Journal.Wednesday  Feb  : PM

title: Flexibility plea on new GP deal
story: THE problems facing GPs in Caithness have been outlined to Scotlandrsquos health secretary Jeane Freeman by two north MSPs.Rhoda Grant and David Stewart.Labour representatives for the Highlands and Islands, met with Ms Freeman to express their concern about the new GP contract and the impact it could have on rural and remote areas.They were accompanied by Phil Wilson, a professor of primary care and rural health at the University of Aberdeen and a GP in Inverness.Also present was a Dingwall GP Miles Mack.Mrs Grant asked Ms Freeman for the face-to-face meeting at the Scottish Parliament and highlighted issues which GPs across the Highlands and Islands have raised with her and Mr Stewart.The doctors told the minister that five of the  permanent GPs in Caithness are likely to retire in the next five years.Ms Freeman heard that since  almost half of all permanent GP posts in the county have been vacant and partially replaced with short-term locum provision.Three practices have ceased to be independent contractors and have been taken over by NHS Highland.Concerns were also raised about the capacity for undergraduate teaching and the effect on retention and recruitment of GPs in remote areas.Doctors have told the MSPs that the new contract fails to recognise the workload in rural areas where surgeries deal with a far greater range of medical problems, including emergencies that would be dealt with in hospitals in urban areas.Mrs Grant said: ldquoThe main concern is that whatrsquos on the table with the new contract is an urban model and this just doesnrsquot suit remote and rural areas.ldquoGPs are worried it will cause poor continuity of care for patients and that procedures currently performed at surgeries are being centralised ndash for instance for blood tests or vaccinations.ldquoThis will inevitably inconvenience patients and worsen health outcomes by raising barriers to care.ldquoThe contract states that other healthcare professionals will be employed to deal with these extra tasks ndash but with rural GP posts remaining unfilled, and shortages of nurses in many areas, how can we expect to find these extra people in our out-of-the-way places ldquoThere must be flexibility for GPs to retain the old system of care.The new contractrsquos funding formula has been based on the number of appointmentsand does not take account of the issues faced by rural areas such as patient and doctor travel.ldquoGPs in our region cannot wait for another three years to see some movement on this and Irsquom hopeful that the health secretary will find a suitable way forward.At the meeting Ms Freeman said she had ldquogenuinely taken the issues seriously and discussion would continue with colleagues. Mrs Grant was promised an update in two months.Wednesday  Feb  : PM

title: Roadworks to be carried out at four Caithness locations
story: ROAD improvements costing pound, are to be carried out at four Caithness locations, starting next week.The work, to be carried out by Bear Scotland, will begin at Hempriggs on the A on Monday and will conclude at Thrumster in April.A spokeswoman for the company said: "We have a pound, programme of road improvements planned across four locations in the Caithness area on the A and A in March and April."Starting on Monday, surfacing improvements will first take place on the A at Hempriggs for  days to address the worn-out road surface and localised rutted sections. Works will then move to the A south of Georgemas for  days from Monday, March , to carry out surfacing improvements on the route."A three-day patching project will then take place on the A Berriedale south brae which will address defects in the road surface, followed by an eight-day surfacing project for a stretch of the A at Thrumster in April."The spokeswoman said the projects will take place during the day, from am to pm, with no work planned at weekends to keep disruption to a minimum. A mph convoy system will be in place during working hours to escort traffic past the works areas at each location."Teams will do all they can to complete the projects as quickly and safely as possible. However, we encourage people to plan their journeys in advance by checking the Traffic Scotland website for up to date journey information," the spokeswoman added.Wick and east Caithness Highland councillor, Raymond Bremner, has been pressing for the road improvements on that section of the A and is "absolutely delighted" they are going ahead."The northbound side of the road has been in a deteriorating state of repair for some time and it certainly looked as though we were needing more than a pothole repair approach," he said. As a result, and after a lot of discussion between the agencies, Bear and Transport Scotland, Irsquom delighted the remedial works are about to start."Wednesday  Feb  : PM

title: Wick Francis Street Club placed in liquidation
story: WICKS Francis Street Club has been placed in liquidation, it was confirmed on Thursday.According to provisional liquidator Iain Fraser, a partner with FRP Advisory, the decision was made following a decline in membership, rising costs and unsustainable cash-flow problems. The club ndash founded in the s as a British Legion ndash has now closed and six staff have been made redundant.Mr Fraser said: "The Francis Street Club has been a landmark social, entertainment and sports venue in Caithness for nearly  years. Sadly, the club has been suffering severe financial problems and liquidation was the only option available to the committee."We are working closely with the relevant agencies, including the Redundancy Payments Office, to ensure the staff receive as much support as possible. We are now offering the assets of the business for sale, including the building, fixtures and fittings, and would urge interested parties to contact our Aberdeen office as soon as possible on   ."The Francis Street Club started was a long-established social, entertainment and sporting venue which attracted some well-known names through its doors, including former world snooker champion Stephen Hendry who staged an exhibition match there.It served as a social club and ran both football and darts teams, both well supported by members.It also operated as an entertainment venue, with music and entertainment acts from across the country putting in appearances to local acclaim.The premises closed last month. At the time, a statement issued by the club said: "It was decided by the committee to close the Francis Street Club and Institute Limited at midnight on Wednesday, January , ."A note subsequently posted on the door read: "We have ceased trading from immediate effect at these premises the Francis Street Club Wick. All other details will follow in due course."Wednesday  Feb  : PM
